countermeasure.name: Proactive risk assessments for data protection
countermeasure.desc:
Proactive risk assessments help identify and mitigate potential risks to data before they lead to security incidents. Heres how to conduct proactive risk assessments for data protection in the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Inventory and Classify Data

  • Data Inventory:
    • Identify all types of data handled by the application (e.g., personal information, payment data, internal business data).
  • Data Classification:
    • Classify data into different sensitivity levels (e.g., public, internal, confidential, restricted).

Step 2: Identify Potential Risks

  • Threat Modeling:
    • Conduct threat modeling exercises to identify threats specific to your application.
    • Consider various attack vectors, including web attacks (e.g., XSS, SQL injection), social engineering, and insider threats.
  • Access Controls:
    • Review current access control measures for potential weaknesses or overly broad permissions.

Step 3: Analyze Existing Security Controls

  • Technical Controls:
    • Review current encryption standards, authentication mechanisms, and access controls.
    • Verify compliance with best practices and industry standards (e.g., NIST, ISO 27001).
  • Organizational Controls:
    • Ensure policies and training align with data protection goals.
    • Review incident response plans and data retention policies.

Step 4: Assess Impact and Likelihood of Risks

  • Impact Analysis:
    • Determine the potential impact of data breaches, unauthorized access, or data loss.
    • Consider regulatory fines, loss of customer trust, and business continuity issues.
  • Likelihood Estimation:
    • Estimate the probability of each risk materializing based on historical data, known vulnerabilities, and threat landscape.

Step 5: Develop Mitigation Strategies

  • Technical Mitigations:
    • Implement encryption (at rest and in transit), secure backups, access controls, and data masking.
  • Organizational Mitigations:
    • Conduct security awareness training, establish incident response procedures, and update policies.
  • Risk Acceptance or Transfer:
    • In some cases, accept risks with compensating controls or transfer them through cyber insurance.

Step 6: Document Findings and Plan

  • Risk Assessment Report:
    • Document identified risks, their potential impacts, and the proposed mitigation strategies.
    • Include a risk matrix or ranking for prioritization.
  • Action Plan:
    • Develop an action plan to implement mitigations, including timelines and responsible parties.

Step 7: Monitor and Review Risks Periodically

  • Continuous Monitoring:
    • Implement continuous monitoring of key risks to detect changes in the threat landscape.
  • Regular Reviews:
    • Conduct regular risk assessment reviews, especially after major changes or incidents.

By proactively assessing risks, you can better protect the "Account" software component's data and reduce the likelihood and impact of potential security incidents.

reference.name: GDPR Data protection impact assessment

countermeasure.name: Regular configuration and vulnerability assessment
countermeasure.desc:
Regular configuration and vulnerability assessments are essential to maintain the security posture of the "Account" software component. Here's how to conduct them effectively:

Step 1: Create an Assessment Schedule

  • Frequency:
    • Perform assessments quarterly, or more frequently for critical systems.
    • Schedule assessments after major changes or updates.

Step 2: Inventory Assets and Configurations

  • Asset Inventory:
    • List all servers, databases, applications, and network components in your environment.
  • Configuration Baselines:
    • Establish secure baseline configurations for each system based on industry best practices (e.g., CIS Benchmarks).

Step 3: Configuration Assessment

  • Review System Configurations:
    • Compare the current configuration of each asset against the secure baseline.
    • Identify deviations that could lead to security vulnerabilities (e.g., unused open ports, weak passwords, disabled encryption).
  • Automate Assessments:
    • Use configuration management tools or scripts to automate the assessment process.

Step 4: Vulnerability Scanning

  • Run Automated Scans:
    • Use vulnerability scanners (e.g., Nessus, OpenVAS) to identify known vulnerabilities in your systems.
    • Include both infrastructure (servers, firewalls) and application-level (web apps, databases) scans.
  • Analyze Results:
    • Review scan results to identify critical vulnerabilities requiring immediate attention.

Step 5: Manual Penetration Testing

  • Test for Misconfigurations:
    • Conduct manual testing to identify security issues that automated scanners might miss.
    • Test for common misconfigurations, such as directory traversal or weak authentication.
  • Simulate Real-World Attacks:
    • Simulate real-world attack scenarios, such as privilege escalation or data exfiltration.

Step 6: Document and Prioritize Findings

  • Risk Assessment:
    • Assign severity levels to each finding based on potential impact and exploitability.
    • Prioritize remediation efforts based on business-critical systems and data.
  • Reports:
    • Provide comprehensive reports to stakeholders, detailing findings, impacts, and remediation recommendations.

Step 7: Implement Remediation Plans

  • Fix Issues Promptly:
    • Apply patches or updates, reconfigure systems, and enforce secure coding practices.
  • Verify Changes:
    • Reassess affected systems to ensure the vulnerabilities have been successfully addressed.

Step 8: Continuous Improvement

  • Feedback Loop:
    • Adjust configuration baselines and assessment procedures based on new vulnerabilities and security incidents.
  • Security Awareness:
    • Train your team to recognize common vulnerabilities and maintain secure configurations.

By following these steps, you can establish a proactive, continuous approach to securing the "Account" software component through regular configuration and vulnerability assessments.

reference.name: CIS Benchmarks for Security Configuration

countermeasure.name: Secure session management practices
countermeasure.desc:
Secure session management is crucial to protect user sessions from hijacking, fixation, and unauthorized access. Here's how to implement secure session management practices for the "Account" software component:

Step 1: Establish Secure Session Tokens

  • Unique Identifiers:
    • Generate session tokens with cryptographically secure randomness, ensuring they're unique and unpredictable.
  • Token Length:
    • Use tokens with sufficient length (at least 128-bit) to prevent guessing or brute-force attacks.
  • Token Storage:
    • Store tokens securely on the server and client side (using secure cookies or HTTP headers).

Step 2: Implement Secure Cookie Settings

  • Secure Attribute:
    • Set the Secure attribute to ensure session cookies are only transmitted over HTTPS.
  • HttpOnly Attribute:
    • Set the HttpOnly attribute to prevent access to cookies via JavaScript.
  • SameSite Attribute:
    • Use the SameSite attribute to prevent cookies from being sent with cross-site requests (prefer SameSite=Strict or Lax).

Step 3: Ensure Session Expiration and Renewal

  • Idle Timeout:
    • Implement an idle timeout (e.g., 15-30 minutes of inactivity) to invalidate inactive sessions.
  • Absolute Timeout:
    • Set an absolute session expiration (e.g., 24 hours) to enforce periodic re-authentication.
  • Token Renewal:
    • Refresh tokens periodically to limit their lifetime, especially after sensitive actions.

Step 4: Mitigate Session Fixation

  • Regenerate Tokens:
    • Generate a new session token on login and other critical transitions (e.g., privilege escalation).
    • Invalidate old tokens to prevent reuse.
  • Token Validation:
    • Verify that tokens match the session state (e.g., user roles) and reject mismatches.

Step 5: Protect Against Session Hijacking

  • IP Address Matching:
    • Optionally associate sessions with client IP addresses or user agents, triggering a re-authentication if they change.
  • Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):
    • Require MFA for critical actions or logins from new devices.
  • Intrusion Detection:
    • Monitor for unusual session activity, such as simultaneous logins from different regions.

Step 6: Implement Logging and Auditing

  • Session Logs:
    • Log session creation, termination, and any security-related actions.
  • Alerting:
    • Set up alerts for suspicious session activities, like repeated token changes or session reuse.

Step 7: Educate Users

  • Security Awareness:
    • Inform users about security best practices (e.g., avoiding shared computers, logging out after use).
  • Self-Service Features:
    • Provide tools for users to view active sessions and terminate any they do not recognize.

By following these practices, you can create a robust session management system that securely handles user sessions in the "Account" software component.

reference.name: NIST 800-63B (B.6 Session Management)
OWASP Secure Session Management Guide

countermeasure.name: Use of secure defaults and hardening guides
countermeasure.desc:
Using secure defaults and hardening guides ensures that the "Account" software component starts from a secure baseline and minimizes its attack surface. Here's how to implement secure defaults and hardening practices effectively:

Step 1: Establish Secure Defaults

Configuration Defaults:

  • Set up application, database, and server configurations with conservative security settings by default.
  • Disable unused services and features that can expand the attack surface (e.g., default database accounts).

Password Policies:

  • Enforce strong default password policies (e.g., minimum length, complexity requirements).
  • Disable or limit default accounts and credentials.

Access Controls:

  • Apply least privilege as the default permission setting for new accounts or roles.
  • Deny access to sensitive features or data unless explicitly permitted.

Secure Transport:

  • Enforce HTTPS as the default transport protocol, redirecting HTTP traffic automatically.
  • Set secure defaults for cookies (e.g., Secure, HttpOnly, SameSite attributes).

Step 2: Apply Hardening Guides

Operating System Hardening:

  • Follow recognized OS hardening guidelines like CIS Benchmarks or government recommendations.
  • Remove unnecessary software packages, disable unused network services, and apply restrictive firewall rules.

Application Hardening:

  • Enable security features like Content Security Policy (CSP) and Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) restrictions.
  • Ensure all third-party libraries or plugins are up-to-date and supported.

Database Hardening:

  • Restrict database access to required users and applications only.
  • Disable unused features and configure secure defaults (e.g., encryption in transit, user auditing).

Network Hardening:

  • Limit network exposure by placing the application behind a web application firewall (WAF) and reverse proxy.
  • Implement logging and intrusion detection for critical traffic.

Step 3: Test Hardening and Secure Defaults

Automated Testing:

  • Integrate automated security testing tools that verify default configurations meet established baselines.
  • Perform regular vulnerability scans to identify misconfigurations and unpatched components.

Manual Testing:

  • Conduct manual security reviews to ensure secure defaults are consistently applied.
  • Validate that hardening configurations are compatible with functional requirements.

Step 4: Update Hardening Guides Regularly

  • Threat Landscape Awareness:
    • Stay informed about emerging threats and vulnerabilities affecting your technology stack.
  • Guideline Updates:
    • Review and update hardening guidelines periodically to reflect changing best practices.
    • Share updated guidelines across the team to ensure consistent implementation.

By implementing these secure defaults and hardening practices, you establish a secure foundation for the "Account" software component and minimize the risk of successful attacks.

reference.name: NIST Guide to General Server Security

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Resource exhaustion through account enumeration attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Resource exhaustion through account enumeration attacks is a form of brute force attack where an attacker attempts to identify valid user accounts within a system by exploiting specific feedback mechanisms, typically through login pages or API responses. Once accounts are identified, the attacker continues to bombard them with numerous authentication attempts. This attack seeks to overwhelm the system's resources (e.g., CPU, memory, bandwidth), often causing degraded performance, denial of service (DoS), or data compromise.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Threat actors often include hackers, organized cybercriminals, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Login forms or APIs that provide differing responses for valid and invalid usernames.
    • Forgot-password or account recovery pages that reveal user account existence.
    • Publicly accessible directories or registration forms that can be exploited for brute force or enumeration attacks.

Impacts

  • Resource Exhaustion: The system's resources become strained due to an excessive number of authentication attempts.
  • Denial of Service (DoS): Other legitimate services can become unavailable due to excessive resource usage.
  • Account Lockout: Valid users may be locked out of their accounts if the system implements automatic lockouts after a certain number of failed login attempts.
  • Data Exposure: Attackers might gather valid usernames or email addresses for future targeted attacks.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: Username Discovery via Login Response

  • An attacker submits multiple usernames in a login form.
  • The system differentiates between valid and invalid usernames via error messages.
  • The attacker identifies active accounts and attempts resource-exhaustion attacks on them.

Scenario 2: Account Lockout by Brute Force

  • An attacker discovers valid usernames via enumeration techniques.
  • They then attempt numerous login attempts, causing legitimate users to be locked out due to the systems security policies.
  • This flood of login attempts strains server resources, slowing down other services.

Scenario 3: Automated Enumeration via API

  • The attacker programs a bot to send rapid API requests.
  • The API's error messages reveal which usernames are valid.
  • The attacker uses these accounts to conduct brute-force password attacks, causing a sharp spike in resource consumption.

Mitigation strategies include rate limiting, CAPTCHA implementations, standardized error messages, and account behavior analysis.

reference.name: OWASP DoS Prevention

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499.001 - OS Exhaustion Flood||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499.002 - Service Exhaustion Flood||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499.003 - Application Exhaustion Flood

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers gain elevated privilege
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

The threat of attackers gaining elevated privilege is a significant concern for software components that handle sensitive data, like an account management system. This type of attack occurs when unauthorized individuals manipulate vulnerabilities within the system to gain privileges above their assigned level. Such unauthorized privilege escalation enables attackers to perform operations they normally couldn't, potentially leading to extensive system compromise.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  1. Threat Agents: The primary threat agents include external hackers, insider threats (disgruntled employees, for instance), and advanced persistent threat (APT) groups targeting critical data. Insider threats often possess initial access credentials, increasing the attacks effectiveness.
  2. Attack Vectors:
    • Vulnerable Software: Bugs or logic flaws in the software allowing users to circumvent privilege verification.
    • Weak Authentication: Poor authentication mechanisms, like insecure password policies or multi-factor authentication misconfigurations.
    • Misconfigured Access Controls: Incorrectly set permissions or policies enabling access beyond the users role.
    • Social Engineering: Phishing or other manipulation techniques to gain initial low-privilege access and then escalate.

Impacts

  1. Data Breach: Access to sensitive personal or financial data stored in the account system.
  2. System Compromise: Complete control over user accounts or administrative functions, leading to further exploitation.
  3. Financial Loss: Theft of funds, fraudulent transactions, or damage to business operations.
  4. Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from clients or partners due to inadequate security.

Example Attack Scenarios

Vulnerable API: An attacker identifies an insecure API endpoint within the account management system. By crafting specific requests that exploit input validation flaws, they manage to execute administrative commands, gaining full system access.

Misconfigured Access Control: An insider user in a non-administrative role discovers that certain backend administrative pages lack proper access controls. By directly accessing these pages, the user bypasses role-based restrictions and modifies account settings for other users.

Brute Force on Admin Account: An attacker gains access to a low-level account through a phishing attack. From there, they analyze username structures and identify an admin user account. They then use brute force techniques to compromise the admin account and escalate their privileges.

Malicious Insider: A disgruntled employee with a customer support role intentionally misuses their elevated permissions to deactivate security features for their account, allowing them unrestricted access to sensitive information.

The potential impacts of these scenarios highlight the need for strong, multi-layered security controls, routine monitoring, and thorough vulnerability management to mitigate risks.

reference.name: OWASP CSRF Prevention

threat.name: Attackers use improper security configuration for malicious activities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Improper security configurations refer to incorrect or suboptimal settings that inadvertently provide attackers with exploitable vulnerabilities. When system components like databases, servers, web applications, or cloud services are misconfigured, attackers can manipulate these settings to bypass authentication, execute malicious code, access sensitive data, or launch further attacks. This improper configuration is often due to default settings, lack of configuration review, or insufficient security policies.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents:

  • Cybercriminals who scan for known vulnerabilities in popular software configurations.
  • Insider threats that leverage their internal knowledge for personal gain or revenge.
  • Script kiddies who use automated tools to exploit misconfigured systems.

Attack Vectors

  • Open ports left unnecessarily exposed to the internet.
  • Databases and directories accessible without proper authentication.
  • Web server files and admin panels left publicly visible.
  • Inadequate permissions on sensitive resources like APIs, storage buckets, or management consoles.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers can gain access to internal networks, systems, and sensitive data.
  • Service Disruption: Manipulating configurations may lead to Denial of Service (DoS), which can disable critical services.
  • Data Breach: Exposure of private data, like customer information or intellectual property, can occur.
  • Privilege Escalation: Attackers may leverage minor misconfigurations to gain administrator-level control over systems.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: Open Management Port

  • A database management port remains publicly accessible with a default or weak password.
  • An attacker locates the port through internet-wide scans and logs into the database.
  • The attacker exfiltrates sensitive customer data.

Scenario 2: Misconfigured Web Server

  • A web server is left with directory browsing enabled, exposing the directory structure and files.
  • An attacker explores these directories, finding configuration files containing credentials.
  • Using these credentials, the attacker accesses internal systems and customer data.

Scenario 3: Publicly Accessible Cloud Storage

  • A cloud storage bucket is misconfigured, leaving it publicly readable and writable.
  • An attacker discovers the bucket and uploads malicious files that redirect legitimate users to phishing sites.
  • Users who download sensitive files from the bucket unknowingly download malware.

Mitigations include implementing security best practices, routine vulnerability scanning, consistent patching, proper access controls, configuration management, and regular security audits.

reference.name: A.12.6.1 Management of Technical Vulnerabilities
CIS Benchmarks
NIST Vulnerability Database
OWASP Secure Configuration Guide

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Information disclosure through improper handling of user data and error messages
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Information disclosure through improper handling of user data and error messages refers to unintentionally exposing sensitive information due to misconfigured system behavior or poor data sanitization practices. This exposure can occur through debugging messages, exception details, or inadvertent data leakage. Attackers can use this information to gain insights into internal workings, identify weaknesses, and subsequently launch more targeted attacks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents:

  • External Hackers: Hackers seeking to discover internal system details to identify exploitable vulnerabilities.
  • Insiders: Malicious or negligent insiders with knowledge of system behavior, leveraging access to error messages or misconfigured components.
  • Competitors/State Actors: Groups seeking competitive or strategic advantage by gathering sensitive or proprietary information.

Attack Vectors:

  • Error Messages: Inadequate handling of error messages that reveal sensitive information, like usernames, system paths, or application structure.
  • Logging Practices: Logging user inputs or sensitive details without appropriate sanitization or encryption.
  • Debugging Information: Exposing detailed debugging information in production environments, which can include database queries or stack traces.
  • Misconfigured Access: Allowing unauthorized users to access sensitive pages due to incorrect access control.

Impacts

  1. Sensitive Information Exposure: Revealing customer data, proprietary business information, or other confidential details.
  2. Security Vulnerability Identification: Allowing attackers to identify internal weaknesses like database structure, server configurations, or software versions.
  3. Reputational Damage: Eroding customer trust by inadvertently disclosing their data.
  4. Legal Consequences: Non-compliance with privacy regulations due to exposure of protected information.

Example Attack Scenarios

Verbose Error Messages: An attacker intentionally triggers error conditions, and verbose error messages disclose sensitive data such as file paths or database query structures that hint at exploitable vulnerabilities.

Logging Insufficient Sanitization: Application logs record user input data without adequate sanitization, exposing personal information or credentials. An attacker who gains access to these logs can read sensitive details.

Debugging Information: A developer leaves detailed debugging messages enabled in production. An attacker sees these messages, which contain database error details, giving clues to the schema and potential injection points.

Access Control Misconfiguration: Error messages generated on unauthorized access attempts reveal information about valid usernames or resources that should be kept hidden.

Mitigation Strategies

  1. Input Validation and Sanitization: Properly validate and sanitize user input before logging or processing.
  2. Controlled Error Messaging: Configure user-facing error messages to be generic while logging detailed technical information securely for administrators.
  3. Production Debugging Policies: Disable debugging information in production environments, ensuring only high-level error messages are visible to end-users.
  4. Access Control Audits: Regularly audit access control configurations to prevent unintended data disclosure.

reference.name: OWASP Error Handling
Secure Error Handling Best Practices

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1589.001 - Credentials||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1592 - Gather Victim Host Information||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1595 - Active Scanning

threat.name: Attackers obtain unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access refers to a situation where attackers gain entry into a software component without proper authorization. For an account management system, this means circumventing authentication or authorization controls to access accounts, user data, or administrative functions. This unauthorized entry often serves as a stepping stone for further attacks such as data exfiltration, privilege escalation, or denial-of-service.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents:

  • External hackers seeking to exploit security flaws to gain access to sensitive systems.
  • Malicious insiders misusing their current privileges to infiltrate restricted parts of the system.
  • Competitors or state-sponsored groups targeting proprietary or personal data.

Attack Vectors:

  • Brute Force Attacks: Repeated attempts to guess passwords until successful, particularly where weak or reused credentials are used.
  • Phishing/Social Engineering: Manipulating users into revealing their credentials or installing malware.
  • Vulnerable APIs or Web Applications: Exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities in application code to bypass authentication mechanisms.
  • Credential Stuffing: Using lists of breached passwords to gain access to accounts using reused passwords.
  • Physical Security Gaps: Directly accessing systems via physical means (e.g., stolen devices or insecure network access).

Impacts

  1. Data Theft: Compromising personally identifiable information (PII), financial data, and proprietary business information.
  2. Account Takeover: Hijacking accounts to conduct fraud, impersonation, or malicious activities under a legitimate users identity.
  3. Service Disruption: Altering or disabling account settings that can disrupt normal service operations.
  4. Legal and Regulatory Penalties: Non-compliance with data security regulations may lead to fines or sanctions.

Example Attack Scenarios

Phishing Attack: An attacker sends convincing phishing emails to employees that mimic an official company email, tricking users into providing their login credentials via a fake login page. The attacker then uses these credentials to gain unauthorized access to the system.

Unpatched Software: An account management application has a known vulnerability that the development team hasn't yet patched. The attacker scans for this software version, exploits the vulnerability to bypass authentication, and gains control over user accounts.

Insider Attack: An employee with legitimate access to user accounts steals login credentials or directly accesses user data, providing this information to an external malicious entity.

Credential Stuffing: The attacker uses a list of known breached passwords from a different service to attempt logins to the account system. Many users reuse passwords, allowing the attacker to successfully log into their accounts.

Mitigation Strategies

To reduce the risks of unauthorized access, consider implementing multi-factor authentication, rate-limiting login attempts, robust security training for employees, and regular audits of software security.

OWASP Session Management Cheat Sheet

threat.name: Attackers take advantage of poor protected data and insecure communications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Attackers exploiting poorly protected data and insecure communications refers to cybercriminals targeting unencrypted, weakly encrypted, or improperly managed sensitive information. This includes data stored locally, transmitted over networks, or accessed through insecure channels. Without strong encryption or secure protocols, attackers can intercept, tamper with, or steal data, leading to financial loss, privacy violations, and further attacks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents

  • Cybercriminals seeking to steal data for financial gain or extortion.
  • Nation-state actors involved in espionage and surveillance activities.
  • Insider threats leveraging insecure data channels for personal or competitive advantage.

Attack Vectors

  • Public Wi-Fi networks that transmit unencrypted data.
  • Web applications using outdated security protocols (e.g., SSL instead of TLS).
  • Storage devices with poor encryption or easily guessable passwords.
  • APIs lacking encryption or access control.
  • Poorly secured file transfers via email, FTP, or other channels.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties, potentially leading to identity theft or intellectual property loss.
  • Financial Loss: Victims may suffer direct financial losses or face costly compliance fines due to the breach.
  • Reputational Damage: Organizations may lose customer trust due to leaked customer data or compromised communication channels.
  • Espionage: Sensitive corporate or governmental data may be stolen for strategic, financial, or political advantage.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: Eavesdropping on Public Wi-Fi

  • An attacker sets up a fake Wi-Fi hotspot in a public location (e.g., caf, airport).
  • Users unknowingly connect to the hotspot, transmitting their personal and business data in plaintext.
  • The attacker intercepts the unencrypted traffic, gaining access to login credentials and sensitive information.

Scenario 2: Insecure Communication Protocol

  • A web application uses outdated or insecure communication protocols like SSL or HTTP instead of HTTPS.
  • The attacker uses a "man-in-the-middle" attack to intercept sensitive data transmitted between the client and server.
  • The attacker gains access to confidential information like passwords and private messages.

Scenario 3: Unprotected Storage Devices

  • An organization stores sensitive data on portable USB drives without encryption.
  • An insider or thief steals the USB drives and accesses the data directly due to a lack of encryption or access control.

Mitigations include encrypting all data at rest and in transit, using secure communication protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2+), regularly updating software, implementing multi-factor authentication, and monitoring data access.

reference.name: GDPR Article 32 - Security of processing
NIST Guide to Data Integrity
NIST Guidelines for Data Encryption
OWASP Top Ten Proactive Controls 2018 (C8)
TLS Best Practices

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Unnoticed misbehaviour due to insufficient logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unnoticed misbehavior due to insufficient logging and monitoring happens when security incidents or malicious activity go undetected because of a lack of comprehensive logging or inadequate monitoring of system events. Without proper logs and real-time alerts, attacks can progress unimpeded, allowing adversaries to cause significant damage or remain persistent in the network for extended periods.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents

  • External attackers who exploit vulnerabilities to gain unauthorized access or compromise systems.
  • Malicious insiders who abuse legitimate privileges for espionage, sabotage, or data theft.
  • Automated bots scanning networks for open ports or insecure services.

Attack Vectors

  • Gaining unauthorized access through weak credentials or unpatched vulnerabilities.
  • Privilege escalation and lateral movement across systems undetected due to missing or weak logging.
  • Disabling or evading logging mechanisms as part of an attack strategy.

Impacts

  • Delayed Incident Response: Without sufficient logging and monitoring, security incidents are recognized too late, increasing response time and potential damage.
  • Extended System Compromise: Attackers can persist in the system, collecting data or spreading malware due to the absence of immediate detection.
  • Data Breach: Compromised data may lead to compliance violations, financial losses, and reputational damage.
  • Business Disruption: Critical services might be disrupted if malicious actions remain undetected.

Example Attack Scenarios

Scenario 1: Web Server Exploitation

  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability in a web application that lacks proper logging.
  • They install a web shell, granting them persistent backdoor access.
  • Without detection mechanisms, the attacker extracts sensitive data over time without being noticed.

Scenario 2: Insider Data Theft

  • An insider downloads a large number of files from internal databases.
  • Because of insufficient logging or lack of alerting thresholds, this activity is not flagged as suspicious.
  • The insider sells or leaks proprietary data externally, unnoticed.

Scenario 3: Ransomware Infection

  • A phishing email delivers a ransomware payload that encrypts files on the infected machine.
  • The compromised device's activity is not logged, so the encryption remains unnoticed.
  • The ransomware spreads across the network, infecting other machines, and eventually leading to a widespread system lockdown.

Mitigation measures include implementing centralized logging systems, ensuring logs are comprehensive and immutable, configuring alerts for unusual activities, and regularly reviewing logs for suspicious patterns. Furthermore, organizations should deploy security information and event management (SIEM) solutions for real-time monitoring and automated alerts.

reference.name: NIST Logging Best Practices
OWASP Log Forging Prevention Cheat Sheet
OWASP Logging Cheat Sheet

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Injection attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Injection attacks occur when attackers insert malicious code into an input field or request to manipulate or exploit a vulnerable software system. This type of attack can lead to unauthorized access, data leakage, data manipulation, and even system compromise. Common forms include SQL injection, cross-site scripting (XSS), and command injection. These attacks leverage unvalidated or improperly sanitized input to execute unintended commands or queries.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat Agents:

  • External Hackers: Cybercriminals seeking unauthorized access or data manipulation via vulnerable input fields.
  • Malicious Insiders: Employees or other internal users who exploit their knowledge of system weaknesses.
  • Automated Bots: Tools specifically designed to scan and exploit injection vulnerabilities on a large scale.

Attack Vectors:

  • SQL Injection: Manipulating SQL queries via web application input fields to gain access to databases or modify data.
  • Cross-Site Scripting (XSS): Injecting client-side scripts into web pages viewed by other users to steal data or compromise their sessions.
  • Command Injection: Injecting operating system commands through an application's input to execute unauthorized actions.
  • LDAP Injection: Exploiting input validation flaws to alter LDAP queries and access sensitive information.

Impacts

  1. Data Theft: Access to sensitive or proprietary data stored in the system.
  2. Data Manipulation: Unauthorized alteration or deletion of records in the database.
  3. Account Compromise: Unauthorized access to user accounts, potentially enabling privilege escalation or session hijacking.
  4. System Control: Complete system compromise, allowing attackers to execute arbitrary commands or deploy malware.

Example Attack Scenarios

SQL Injection: An attacker submits a crafted input, such as '; DROP TABLE users; --, into a vulnerable web form that executes SQL queries without proper sanitization. This input tricks the database into deleting the entire user table.

Cross-Site Scripting (XSS): An attacker injects a <script> tag into a comment section of a web page, exploiting the application's lack of input filtering. When other users view the page, their browsers execute the script, sending their session cookies to the attacker.

Command Injection: An application allows users to execute system commands via a web interface. An attacker injects commands like ; rm -rf / into a field, causing the server to delete important files.

LDAP Injection: An attacker submits malicious input to manipulate an LDAP search query, enabling them to gain unauthorized access to parts of the LDAP directory.

Mitigation Strategies

  1. Input Validation and Sanitization: Ensure that all user inputs are validated and sanitized before being processed or stored.
  2. Parameterized Queries/Prepared Statements: Use parameterized queries for database operations to prevent SQL injection.
  3. Content Security Policy (CSP): Implement CSP to mitigate the impact of XSS attacks.
  4. Least Privilege Principle: Limit user access rights to the minimum required for their roles.
  5. Error Handling and Logging: Implement proper error handling to avoid exposing sensitive details, and log suspicious activities for further analysis.

reference.name: OWASP SQL Injection Prevention Cheat Sheet
OWASP XSS Prevention Cheat Sheet
Secure Coding Practices

weakness.name: CWE-1188
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1188: Initialization of a Resource with an Insecure Default The product initializes or sets a resource with a default that is intended to be changed by the administrator, but the default is not secure.

weakness.name: CWE-209
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-209: Generation of Error Message Containing Sensitive Information The product generates an error message that includes sensitive information about its environment, users, or associated data.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-829
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-829: Inclusion of Functionality from Untrusted Control Sphere The product imports, requires, or includes executable functionality (such as a library) from a source that is outside of the intended control sphere.

countermeasure.name: Enable termination protection on production or critical CloudFormation stacks
countermeasure.desc:
Turn on stack termination protection for every CloudFormation stack that hosts production or otherwise business-critical resources. Termination protection prevents an accidental DeleteStack operationwhether issued from the console, CLI, API, or by an automated pipelinefrom tearing down live infrastructure.

How to implement

  1. During stack creation
    • Console: Create stack Configure stack options check Enable termination protection.
    • AWS CLI / IaC:
    • aws cloudformation create-stack \
       --stack-name prod-network \
       --enable-termination-protection \
       --template-body file://network.yml
  2. For existing stacks
  3. aws cloudformation update-termination-protection \
     --stack-name prod-network \
     --enable-termination-protection
  4. Guardrails
    • Embed TerminationProtection: true or the corresponding CLI flag in every production pipeline so the protection cant be skipped by mistake.
    • Add an SCP or IAM policy that denies cloudformation:DeleteStack unless the request includes the condition aws:RequestTag{"Environment":"Sandbox"}.
    • Use AWS Config rule cloudformation-termination-protection-enabled (or a custom rule) to alert if a critical stack lacks the setting.
  5. Operational procedure
    • If you truly need to remove a protected stack, require a two-person review to first disable termination protection and then run the delete.
    • Log both actions with CloudTrail and notify the Security or SRE channel via EventBridge SNS.

Enabling termination protection provides a simple but highly effective safeguard against catastrophic, irreversible deletions in production accounts.

References

  • Protect a stack from being accidentally deleted (AWS CloudFormation)

countermeasure.name: Ensure templates containing sensitive information are stored securely
countermeasure.desc:
Any CloudFormation template that contains secrets, connection strings, or architecture details must reside only in encrypted storage with tightly scoped access:

  1. Choose an encrypted repository
    • CodeCommit (encrypted at rest with AWS-owned KMS keys), an S3 bucket with SSE-KMS, or a Git service hosted inside an encrypted EBS/EFS volume.
  2. Lock down access
    • Grant least-privilege IAM permissionsread/write only to DevOps roles and your CI/CD service role.
    • Require MFA for console access and Git pushes; enable branch protection to stop force-pushes or secret rewrites.
  3. Encrypt in transit
    • Enforce HTTPS/TLS for Git and S3; block HTTP with bucket policies ("aws:SecureTransport":"false").
  4. Remove or externalize secrets
    • Reference sensitive values through SSM Parameter Store or Secrets Manager parameters rather than hard-coding them.
    • If a template must embed data (for example, a Lambda ZIP hash), encrypt the file using AWS KMS-encrypted artifacts before storing.
  5. Continuous monitoring
    • Enable AWS Config rules (or Git hooks) that flag unencrypted buckets or repositories with public access.
    • Run secret-scanning tools (git-secrets, truffleHog) in your pipeline; fail builds if new credentials appear.
  6. Audit & rotate
    • Quarterly, review repository IAM policies and KMS key policies; rotate encryption keys per compliance policy.
    • Use CloudTrail and CodeCommit access logs to detect unusual reads or clones.

Securing storage for sensitive templates prevents credential leakage, intellectual-property exposure, and supply-chain tampering before infrastructure is even deployed.

References

  • Protect sensitive data in CloudFormation templates AWS Docs
  • Encrypt and control access to CodeCommit and S3 repositories

countermeasure.name: Implement code review processes for CloudFormation templates
countermeasure.desc:
Treat every CloudFormation template like application code: commit it to version control and block deployment until it has passed an automated scan and been approved by at least one qualified reviewer.

Implementation guidance

  1. Source-control first Store templates in a Git repository (AWS CodeCommit, GitHub, Bitbucket). Enable branch-protection rules that:
    • Force pull requests (PRs) for every change.
    • Require a minimum of one reviewer for dev stacks and two for production-bound stacks.
    • Block direct pushes to the main or release branches.
  2. Automated checks in the PR pipeline
    • Run cfn-lint to catch syntax errors and IAM typo-policies.
    • Run CloudFormation Guard or cfn-nag rules to enforce organisational policies (for example, no public S3 buckets, encryption required, termination protection enabled).
    • Fail the PR if any check returns a non-zero exit code.
  3. Human review focus areas
    • Validate logical changes (new resources, deletions, capability flags).
    • Confirm IAM policies are least-privilege and scoped to specific ARNs.
    • Ensure parameters do not hard-code secretsuse SSM or Secrets Manager instead.
    • Verify that stack tags include environment, owner, and cost-centre metadata.
  4. Merge & deploy
    • After approvals and green checks, merge to the protected branch that triggers the deployment pipeline (CodePipeline, GitHub Actions, etc.).
    • Require a second approval or change-control ticket when the pipeline targets a production account.
  5. Continuous improvement
    • Review rejected PRs quarterly to refine linter rules.
    • Rotate reviewers to avoid knowledge silos and keep security knowledge current.

A disciplined review workflow catches misconfigurations and privilege-escalation paths early, preventing insecure infrastructure from ever reaching an AWS account.

References

  • AWS CloudFormation security best practices treat templates as code
  • AWS CloudFormation Guard policy as code for template validation

countermeasure.name: Store CloudFormation templates in S3 buckets configured with server-side encryption
countermeasure.desc:
When you keep packaged CloudFormation templates ( .yaml, .json, or ZIP archives referenced with TemplateURL and AWS::Include ) in Amazon S3, place them only in buckets that use server-side encryption (SSE):

  1. Choose the encryption mode
    • SSE-KMS with a customer-managed key (recommended) for full control over key rotation and granular access via key policy.
    • SSE-S3 if you do not need separate key management but still want 256-bit encryption at rest.
  2. Configure the bucket
    • In the console: Properties Default encryption Enable and select AWS KMS key or SSE-S3.
    • With the CLI:
      • aws s3api put-bucket-encryption \
         --bucket cf-templates-prod \
         --server-side-encryption-configuration \
         '{"Rules":[{"ApplyServerSideEncryptionByDefault":{"SSEAlgorithm":"aws:kms","KMSMasterKeyID":"alias/cfn-templates"}}]}'
  3. Block plaintext uploads with a bucket policy that denies s3:PutObject when the request lacks encryption headers:
    1. {
       "Sid":"DenyUnencryptedObjectUploads",
       "Effect":"Deny",
       "Principal":"*",
       "Action":"s3:PutObject",
       "Resource":"arn:aws:s3:::cf-templates-prod/*",
       "Condition":{"StringNotEquals":{"s3:x-amz-server-side-encryption":"aws:kms"}}
      }
  4. Restrict access
    • Grant read permissions only to the CI/CD role that packages or validates templates and the CloudFormation service principal in the target account.
    • Enable Bucket Versioning and MFA delete to protect against overwrites and accidental removals.
  5. Validate continuously
    • Deploy the AWS Config managed rule s3-bucket-server-side-encryption-enabled (or a custom rule scoped to template buckets) so any unencrypted object or new bucket triggers an alert.
    • Include secret-scanning tools in the pipeline to ensure sensitive data is not stored in plaintext inside the templates themselves.

Securing template artifacts with SSE guarantees that infrastructure code is encrypted at rest, satisfies compliance frameworks requiring data-at-rest protection, and prevents inadvertent exposure if the bucket or snapshots are copied elsewhere.

References

  • Protecting data at rest using server-side encryption Amazon S3

countermeasure.name: Use CloudFormation drift detection regularly
countermeasure.desc:
Schedule an automated workflow that runs CloudFormation drift detection on every production or compliance-sensitive stack (for example, nightly or after each deployment). Detecting drift early reveals unapproved manual changessuch as altered security-group rules, missing resources, or changed IAM policiesso you can remediate before they become security incidents.

Implementation guidance

  1. Automate the scan
    • Use an EventBridge rule or CI/CD job that calls aws cloudformation detect-stack-drift --stack-name <stack> for each critical stack.
    • Capture the returned drift detection ID, then poll describe-stack-drift-detection-status until DetectionStatus is DETECTION_COMPLETE.
  2. Alert on drift
    • If StackDriftStatus equals DRIFTED, publish a message to an SNS topic tied to your on-call or ticketing system. Include a link to the consoles Drift details page for fastest triage.
  3. Establish remediation procedures
    • Legitimate change? Update the template and re-deploy so CloudFormation regains control.
    • Unapproved change? Roll back manually or use cloudformation update-stack with the original template.
  4. Harden against future drift
    • Enforce IAM least privilege so only CI/CD roles can mutate stack resources.
    • Enable stack termination protection and lock down the consoles/CLI in production accounts.
  5. Report & audit
    • Store drift results in an S3 bucket or Security Lake for compliance evidence.
    • Review quarterly to confirm scan cadence, add new stacks, and refine alert thresholds.

Regular drift detection keeps your live environment faithful to the version-controlled template, prevents configuration creep, and supports audit requirements for change control.

References

  • Detecting unmanaged configuration changes with CloudFormation drift detection
  • Automating drift detection with AWS CloudFormation and EventBridg

countermeasure.name: Use IAM condition keys to restrict which templates can be used
countermeasure.desc:
Limit stack and change-set operations so they can only use templates stored in your approved S3 locations (or specific signed URLs) by adding the cloudformation:TemplateURL condition key to every IAM policy, role, or Service Control Policy (SCP) that allows cloudformation:CreateStack*, cloudformation:UpdateStack*, or cloudformation:CreateChangeSet.

Implementation steps

  1. Pick the allowed repositories e.g., an SSE-KMSencrypted bucket cf-templates-prod-<acct-id> and, if needed, a staging bucket for non-prod.
  2. Author the policy
    1. {
       "Version": "2012-10-17",
       "Statement": [
         {
           "Effect": "Allow",
           "Action": [
             "cloudformation:CreateStack",
             "cloudformation:UpdateStack",
             "cloudformation:CreateChangeSet"
           ],
           "Resource": "*",
           "Condition": {
             "StringLike": {
               "cloudformation:TemplateURL": [
                 "https://cf-templates-prod-123456789012.s3.amazonaws.com/*"
               ]
             }
           }
         }
       ]
      }
  3. Use StringEquals for exact URLs or StringLike with wildcards for a bucket prefix.
  4. Attach where it matters
    • Production deployment role.
    • CI/CD service role.
    • An organization-wide SCP to stop rogue console/API usage in member accounts.
  5. Block inline templates if required add a Deny statement for RequestTag{"cfn-inline":"true"} or detect the absence of cloudformation:TemplateURL via Null conditions.
  6. Test attempt to deploy a stack that points to an unapproved bucket; the call should fail with AccessDenied (error code ThrottlingException / AccessDenied).
  7. Monitor & review use CloudTrail Lake or Athena to query for cloudformation:CreateStack events where requestParameters.templateURL does not start with your bucket path, and alert if any are found.

Enforcing this condition key stops attackersor well-meaning but careless engineersfrom importing templates that were never peer-reviewed, scanned, or stored in your controlled repository.

References

  • IAM condition keys for AWS CloudFormation

countermeasure.name: Use linting tools and SAST tools to scan templates for potential security misconfigurations
countermeasure.desc:
Add an automated stage to every CI/CD pipeline that runs infrastructure-as-code (IaC) linters and static application security-testing (SAST) tools against your CloudFormation templates. This stage blocks the merge or deployment if it detects syntax errors, insecure defaults, or policy violations.

Implementation guidance

  1. Select your scanners
    • cfn-lint for specification and regional-rule validation.
    • CloudFormation Guard (cfn-guard) or cfn-nag / Checkov / Snyk IaC for security and compliance rules (encryption required, no public resources, least-privilege IAM, etc.).
  2. Integrate into the pipeline
    • Add a dedicated Template Scan job in CodeBuild, GitHub Actions, or your chosen runner.
    • Fail the build on any ERROR from cfn-lint or any rule violation from the SAST toolset. Publish human-readable reports in the PR for reviewers.
  3. Maintain a rules repository
    • Store custom Guard or Nag rules in version control alongside the templates, and review them just like code.
    • Tag each rule with severity so non-blocking WARN findings dont halt lower-environment builds but still surface in reports.
  4. Continuously improve
    • Track recurring findings; harden your base modules so the same issue stops appearing.
    • Update tool versions and rule packs regularlyespecially after new AWS services or vulnerabilities are announced.
  5. Audit & alert
    • Export scan results to Security Hub or a central dashboard so security teams can spot trends.
    • Require an exception ticket, signed off by a security lead, for any deployment that must bypass a critical finding.

By enforcing automated linting and security scanning, you catch misconfigurationslike open security groups, unencrypted storage, or overly broad IAM policiesbefore they ever reach an AWS account, greatly reducing the risk of production vulnerabilities.

References

  • CloudFormation Guard policy-as-code for security & compliance

countermeasure.name: Use NoEcho property for CloudFormation to mask the value in logs and console
countermeasure.desc:
When a CloudFormation template needs a secretsuch as a database password, API key, or license tokendeclare it as a Parameter and set NoEcho: true. CloudFormation will replace the value with asterisks ( ***** ) in the console, CLI, SDK responses, and CloudTrail logs, preventing accidental exposure.

Implementation steps

  1. Define the parameter
    1. Parameters:
       DbPassword:
         Type: String
         NoEcho: true
         Description: "RDS master password (will be masked)"
  2. Reference the parameter wherever the secret is required (for example, in AWS::RDS::DBInstance MasterUserPassword).
  3. Pass the value securely at deploy time:
    • CLI: aws cloudformation create-stack --parameters ParameterKey=DbPassword,ParameterValue="$(aws secretsmanager get-secret-value )"
    • CI/CD: read from Secrets Manager or SSM Parameter Store and inject via a secure variable.
  4. Understand the limits NoEcho masks values in stack descriptions and events but does not hide data you copy into the Metadata or Outputs sections; never echo secrets there.
  5. Enforce in review pipelines add a lint rule (cfn-guard, cfn-nag) that fails the build if any parameter whose name contains Password, Token, or Secret lacks NoEcho: true.

Using NoEcho ensures that sensitive inputs stay confidential throughout the stack life-cycle while still letting templates remain fully declarative.

References

  • CloudFormation parameters syntax
  • General template snippets

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1042 - Disable or Remove Feature or Program
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Use stack policies with Deny statements for the Update:Delete or Delete actions
countermeasure.desc:
Attach a CloudFormation stack policy to every production or high-value stack that explicitly denies the actions Update:Delete, Update:Replace, and Delete for the resources you cannot afford to lose (for example, stateful databases, KMS keys, or VPCs). This prevents accidental or malicious template updates from tearing down or replacing critical infrastructure.

Implementation steps

  1. Author the policy JSON start with a blanket deny that blocks destructive updates, then whitelist resources that may be safely replaced:
    1. {
       "Statement": [
         {
           "Effect": "Deny",
           "Action": [ "Update:*", "Delete:*" ],
           "Principal": "*",
           "Resource": "*"
         },
         {
           "Effect": "Allow",
           "Action": "Update:*",
           "Principal": "*",
           "Resource": [
             "LogicalResourceId/StatelessALB",
             "LogicalResourceId/LambdaFunction*"
           ]
         }
       ]
      }
  2. Apply the policy
    • At creation:
      • aws cloudformation create-stack \
         --stack-name prod-app \
         --template-body file://template.yml \
         --stack-policy-body file://policy.json
    • On existing stacks:
      aws cloudformation set-stack-policy --stack-name prod-app --stack-policy-body file://policy.json
  3. Override only when necessary if a legitimate change needs to modify a protected resource, supply a temporary update-time policy with --stack-policy-during-update-body, execute the update, then restore the original deny policy.
  4. Automate and audit
    • Bake the policy file into your IaC repo and apply it automatically in your deployment pipeline.
    • Enable an AWS Config custom rule (or Security Hub control) that flags stacks whose StackPolicy property is null or differs from the approved baseline.
    • Monitor CloudTrail for SetStackPolicy, UpdateStack, or DeleteStack events and alert on any operation that first removes the deny rules.

Using deny-first stack policies adds a hardened guardrail: even if someone has UpdateStack or DeleteStack permission, CloudFormation itself will refuse operations that could delete or replace protected resources unless a controlled override is in place.

References

  • Prevent updates to stack resources with stack policies
  • Configuring stack policies for least privilege

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Accidental deletion of critical infrastructure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unintentional removal of CloudFormation stacks or resourcesdue to manual errors, template misconfigurations, or faulty automationcan destroy critical infrastructure.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Negligent admins running DeleteStack on the wrong environment
  • Templates or change sets lacking Retain policies
  • CI/CD pipelines applying malformed updates or drift-remediation scripts

Impacts

  • Immediate service outages
  • Irretrievable data loss
  • Extended recovery times and SLA breaches

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An operator accidentally deletes the prod stack instead of dev in the console.
  2. A template update omits DeletionPolicy: Retain on an RDS instance, causing its deletion during deployment.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized stack operations by overly permissive IAM principals
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When IAM principals (users, roles, or service accounts) have overly broad CloudFormation permissionssuch as cloudformation:* on *they can perform stack operations (create, update, delete) beyond their legitimate scope, leading to unauthorized modifications or destruction of infrastructure.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM credentials, and overlyprivileged automation roles.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Wildcard IAM policies granting cloudformation:* on all resources.
    • Misscoped servicelinked roles or crossaccount trusts.
    • Phishing or exploit of privileged accounts to gain leftover CloudFormation rights.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Resource Changes: Creation of malicious stacks or deletion of critical ones.
  • Data Loss & Outages: Destruction of databases, networking, or compute resources.
  • Cost Overruns: Spinning up expensive infrastructure.
  • Compliance Failures: Untracked changes breach audit requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Compromised Role Abuse: An attacker who phishes a DevOps engineers credentials uses their cloudformation:* role to delete production stacks.
  2. Automation Misconfiguration: A CI/CD service role with unrestricted stackupdate rights is hijacked to inject backdoored resources.
  3. CrossAccount Exploit: Overly permissive crossaccount trust lets an external AWS account delete your critical stacks.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data embedded or passed insecurely into templates
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Embedding secrets (passwords, API keys, certificates) directly in CloudFormation templatesor passing them via unsecured parametersexposes sensitive data whenever those templates are accessed, versioned, or logged.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, compromised CI/CD systems
  • Vectors:
    • Checking templates with hardcoded secrets into code repos or public S3 buckets
    • Passing plaintext parameters in CLI/console history or CloudTrail logs
    • Exporting stack parameters to logs or notifications without redaction

Impacts

  • Secret Leakage: Attackers obtain credentials to pivot into other systems
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of datahandling mandates (PCIDSS, HIPAA)
  • Attack Facilitation: Exposed infrastructure details enable targeted exploits

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A developer commits a template containing an RDS master password to GitHub; attackers clone it and connect to the database.
  2. An automated deployment logs parameter values (including API tokens) in CloudWatch; a malicious insider reads the logs to harvest credentials.
  3. A CloudFormation change notification emails full parameter sets to a distribution list, inadvertently revealing SSH keys to unauthorized recipients.

threat.name: Disclosure of template content stored insecurely
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
CloudFormation templates often embed parameters, mappings, or metadata. If these templates are stored without proper access controls or encryptionsuch as in public S3 buckets or unsecured code reposattackers can retrieve sensitive data or infrastructure details.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, compromised CI/CD systems
  • Vectors:
    • Public or misconfigured S3 buckets containing templates
    • Sourcecontrol repositories with weak permissions
    • CI/CD artifacts exposed via unsecured artifact stores

Impacts

  • Secret Leakage: Hardcoded passwords, keys, or ARNs are exposed
  • Reconnaissance: Attackers learn infrastructure topology and roles
  • Attack Facilitation: Sensitive parameters guide targeted exploits

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A public S3 bucket used for template storage is crawled by an attacker, who downloads a template containing database passwords.
  2. A GitHub repo with lax permissions leaks templates embedding IAM role ARNs and EC2 instance IDs, enabling precise phishing.
  3. A CI pipelines artifact store exposes unencrypted templates; a malicious insider retrieves them to map out VPC and subnet configurations for later intrusion.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Configuration drift leading to insecure or unknown states
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Configuration drift occurs when live AWS resources diverge from their CloudFormation templates due to outofband changes. This unsynchronized state can introduce insecure settings, orphaned resources, or unknown dependencies that arent captured in your infrastructure as code.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, DevOps engineers making ad hoc fixes, and rogue automation scripts.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Manual console edits to security groups, IAM policies, or resource properties without updating the stack.
    • External tools or scripts provisioning resources outside CloudFormation.
    • Forgotten template updates after patching or scaling activities.

Impacts

  • Security Gaps: Unintended open ports, weak encryption settings, or outdated AMIs introduce vulnerabilities.
  • Compliance & Audit Failures: Drifted resources fall out of alignment with approved configurations, breaking governance.
  • Operational Uncertainty: Stack updates or deletions may fail or revert critical live changes, increasing downtime and risk.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Orphaned SSH Access: A support engineer opens SSH on a production EC2 security group for troubleshooting but never updates the templateleaving the instance exposed long term.
  2. Untracked Snapshot Creation: Automated backup scripts create EBS snapshots outside of CF; when the stack is deleted, these snapshots persist, revealing sensitive data.
  3. Vulnerable AMI Drift: A manual patch replaces CF-managed instances with a new AMI; the template still references the old, vulnerable AMI, causing future rollbacks to redeploy insecure hosts.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1612 - Build Image on Host

threat.name: Deployment of insecure or malicious infrastructure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Provisioning resources via compromised or poorly vetted CloudFormation templates can spin up insecure or malicious infrastructuresuch as open firewalls, backdoored compute, or overly permissive IAM rolesundermining your security posture from the outset.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised CI/CD pipelines, supplychain attackers
  • Attack Vectors: Injecting malicious code into shared templates; using untrusted community templates; hijacking template repositories or artifact stores

Impacts

  • Backdoor Access: Attackercontrolled instances or management interfaces
  • Privilege Escalation: Overly broad IAM roles grant unintended rights
  • Data Exposure & Exfiltration: Open storage buckets or network ports leak sensitive data
  • Persistence: Malicious resources remain hidden in IaC until redeployment

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A CI pipeline pulls a tampered template that creates an EC2 instance with a backdoor user account, giving the attacker remote shell access.
  2. A team uses an Internet-sourced VPC template that unintentionally opens all subnets to the Internet, exposing databases and admin APIs.
  3. An attacker compromises the template artifact store and injects a Lambda function with wide iam:PassRole permissions, allowing escalation to full-account takeover.

weakness.name: CWE-1190
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1190: DMA Device Enabled Too Early in Boot Phase The product enables a Direct Memory Access (DMA) capable device before the security configuration settings are established, which allows an attacker to extract data from or gain privileges on the product.

weakness.name: CWE-184
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-184: Incomplete List of Disallowed Inputs The product implements a protection mechanism that relies on a list of inputs (or properties of inputs) that are not allowed by policy or otherwise require other action to neutralize before additional processing takes place, but the list is incomplete, leading to resultant weaknesses. Developers often try to protect their products against malicious input by performing tests against inputs that are known to be bad, such as special characters that can invoke new commands. However, such lists often only account for the most well-known bad inputs. Attackers may be able to find other malicious inputs that were not expected by the developer, allowing them to bypass the intended protection mechanism.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-532
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-532: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

countermeasure.name: Deploy CodeBuild projects within a VPC for network isolation
countermeasure.desc: Deploy AWS CodeBuild projects within a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) to ensure that build environments are isolated from external networks, thereby reducing exposure to external threats. Configure your VPC with appropriate security groups and network access control lists (ACLs) to control inbound and outbound traffic to the build environments. This setup ensures that only authorized internal resources can communicate with the CodeBuild environment, enhancing the security of the build process. Additionally, leverage VPC endpoints for secure access to AWS services without traversing the public internet. Implementing this control helps safeguard your build environments against unauthorized access and network-based attacks.

reference.name: Use AWS CodeBuild with Amazon Virtual Private Cloud

PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

countermeasure.name: Encrypt build artifacts at rest in S3
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all build artifacts generated by AWS CodeBuild are stored in Amazon S3 with encryption enabled at rest. This prevents unauthorized access to sensitive data by protecting the artifacts using AWS-managed encryption keys (SSE-S3) or customer-managed keys (SSE-KMS). To implement this control, configure the S3 bucket that stores your build artifacts to enable server-side encryption (SSE) by default. Review and validate that all existing and new artifacts are encrypted at rest. This practice helps maintain the confidentiality and integrity of your build outputs, mitigating the risk of data breaches.

reference.name: Data encryption

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Enforce strict input validation in build scripts
countermeasure.desc: Implement strict validation of all inputs used within AWS CodeBuild scripts to prevent code injection attacks. Ensure that any parameters, environment variables, or external data consumed by build scripts are thoroughly validated for correctness, format, and security. Incorporate validation checks within the build scripts to sanitize inputs, rejecting any malformed or potentially malicious data before it is processed. Use allowlists, regular expressions, and secure coding practices to further reduce the risk of injection vulnerabilities. This control helps maintain the integrity and security of your build process by preventing unauthorized code execution.

reference.name: Security in AWS CodeBuild

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

countermeasure.name: Regularly update build environments with latest patches and software versions
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS CodeBuild environments are consistently updated with the latest security patches and software versions. This includes regularly reviewing and applying updates to the underlying operating systems, libraries, and dependencies used within your build environments. Automate the update process where possible by utilizing AWS services such as AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager or incorporating patching steps into your CI/CD pipeline. Regularly verify that your build environments are up-to-date to minimize vulnerabilities and protect against potential security threats. Maintaining current software versions is critical for the security and stability of your build processes.

reference.name: Docker images provided by CodeBuild

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to S3 buckets for build artifacts
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that access to S3 buckets storing AWS CodeBuild artifacts is tightly controlled by implementing strict permissions. Configure bucket policies and IAM roles to allow access only to authorized users and services that require it. Utilize the principle of least privilege by granting the minimum necessary permissions for accessing, modifying, or managing the build artifacts. Additionally, consider enabling logging and monitoring of access to these S3 buckets using AWS CloudTrail and Amazon S3 access logs to detect any unauthorized access attempts. Proper access control ensures the confidentiality and integrity of your build artifacts.

reference.name: Security in AWS CodeBuild

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Sanitize build logs to remove sensitive data
countermeasure.desc: Implement log sanitization processes within AWS CodeBuild to ensure that any sensitive data, such as credentials, API keys, or personally identifiable information (PII), is removed or obfuscated before logs are stored or shared. This can be achieved by incorporating log filtering mechanisms in your build scripts or using custom logging configurations that exclude sensitive information. Regularly audit and review build logs to identify and address any inadvertent exposure of sensitive data. By sanitizing logs, you protect sensitive information from unauthorized access and reduce the risk of data leakage.

reference.name: Help protect sensitive log data with masking

countermeasure.name: Use approved and hardened build images
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that only approved and security-hardened build images are used in AWS CodeBuild projects. Maintain a curated list of build images that have been vetted for security vulnerabilities and are configured according to your organization's security standards. Regularly update these images to include the latest security patches and remove outdated or vulnerable ones. Enforce the use of these approved images by restricting the selection of build environments in your CodeBuild project configurations. This control helps minimize the risk of executing malicious scripts and enhances the overall security of your build process.
