usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Sensitive data in logs
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data in logs occurs when confidential information, such as credentials or personal data, is inadvertently recorded in AWS CodeBuild logs. This can lead to unauthorized access if the logs are improperly secured or accessed by unauthorized parties.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, unauthorized users, or external attackers.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Accessing logs that contain sensitive data.
    • Exploiting insufficient log sanitization processes to retrieve confidential information.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive information leading to potential data leaks or identity theft.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust and credibility if sensitive data is exposed.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of data protection regulations, possibly resulting in legal penalties and fines.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Access: An attacker gains access to CodeBuild logs and extracts exposed API keys or credentials, which they then use to compromise other systems.
  2. Internal Data Leak: A developer inadvertently logs sensitive customer information, which is later accessed by an unauthorized internal user, leading to a data breach.
  3. Compliance Breach: Logs containing personal data are accessed without proper controls, violating data protection laws and resulting in regulatory action.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Insufficient network isolation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insufficient network isolation in AWS CodeBuild occurs when the build environment is not properly segregated from other network resources. This lack of isolation exposes the build environment to potential external threats, allowing unauthorized access, data leakage, or interference with build processes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, compromised internal systems, or malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of network misconfigurations to gain access to the build environment.
    • Lateral movement from other compromised resources within the same network.

Impacts

  • Security Breach: Unauthorized access to the build environment, leading to potential data theft or code tampering.
  • Operational Disruption: Interference with build processes, potentially resulting in failed builds or deployment of compromised code.
  • Compliance Risks: Non-compliance with security standards requiring network segmentation, possibly leading to regulatory fines.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. External Attack: An attacker exploits an unprotected network segment to gain access to CodeBuild and injects malicious code into the build pipeline.
  2. Lateral Movement: A compromised server within the same network is used to access and tamper with the build environment due to lack of network segmentation.
  3. Data Exfiltration: An attacker intercepts sensitive data transmitted between the build environment and other resources due to inadequate network isolation.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Compromised build environments
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

A compromised build environment occurs when an attacker gains unauthorized access to the infrastructure or resources used by AWS CodeBuild. This can result in the manipulation of the build process, introduction of malicious code, or exposure of sensitive data. A compromised build environment undermines the security of the entire CI/CD pipeline and can lead to severe downstream impacts on deployed applications.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, or compromised third-party tools.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of vulnerabilities in the build environment or associated infrastructure.
    • Unauthorized access due to weak security controls or misconfigurations in the build environment.

Impacts

  • Integrity Loss: Unauthorized modifications to the build process or outputs, leading to the deployment of compromised or malicious software.
  • Data Exposure: Leakage of sensitive information, including source code, credentials, and configuration files.
  • Operational Disruption: Interruption or sabotage of the build process, causing delays or deployment of flawed applications.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Infrastructure Exploit: An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the underlying infrastructure hosting the build environment, gaining control over the build process and inserting malicious code into the final product.
  2. Misconfiguration Abuse: Due to a misconfiguration, an unauthorized user gains access to the build environment, modifies build scripts, and causes the deployment of compromised software.
  3. Third-Party Tool Compromise: A third-party tool integrated into the build environment is compromised, allowing an attacker to manipulate the build process or steal sensitive data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1195.002 - Compromise Software Supply Chain

threat.name: Code injection via build scripts
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Code injection via build scripts occurs when an attacker or unauthorized user introduces malicious code into the build scripts used by AWS CodeBuild. This malicious code can then be executed during the build process, potentially compromising the integrity of the build, leaking sensitive data, or introducing vulnerabilities into the final software product.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, or compromised CI/CD systems.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Inserting malicious code directly into build scripts or configurations.
    • Exploiting vulnerabilities in third-party dependencies or plugins used in the build process.

Impacts

  • Compromised Software Integrity: Malicious code could be embedded in the final software product, leading to security vulnerabilities or backdoors.
  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive information might be extracted and sent to unauthorized parties during the build process.
  • Operational Disruption: The build process could be sabotaged, resulting in failed builds or deployment of insecure code.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Script Manipulation: An attacker gains access to the build script repository and injects malicious code that exfiltrates sensitive data during the build process, which is then sent to an external server.
  2. Third-Party Dependency Exploit: A malicious actor exploits a vulnerability in a third-party library or plugin integrated into the build script, leading to the execution of unauthorized code during the build.
  3. Insider Attack: A disgruntled employee inserts malicious code into the build scripts, which, once deployed, opens a backdoor in the application for future exploitation.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

threat.name: Unauthorized access to build artifacts
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access to build artifacts occurs when individuals or entities gain access to the files, binaries, or other outputs generated by AWS CodeBuild without proper authorization. This can lead to the exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized code changes, or distribution of compromised software.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, unauthorized internal users, or compromised build systems.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting misconfigured S3 bucket permissions where build artifacts are stored.
    • Gaining access through over-permissioned IAM roles associated with the build environment.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive or proprietary code and data contained in build artifacts.
  • Operational Risk: Deployment of compromised or altered software, leading to potential security vulnerabilities.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer trust if compromised artifacts are distributed.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Misconfigured S3 Bucket: An attacker exploits a publicly accessible S3 bucket containing build artifacts, downloads the artifacts, and discovers sensitive information or injects malicious code.
  2. Internal Misuse: An insider with excessive permissions accesses build artifacts and modifies them, leading to the deployment of unauthorized code in a production environment.
  3. Artifact Tampering: An attacker gains access to artifacts stored in an insecure location, alters the files, and these compromised files are later deployed, resulting in a security breach.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1500 - Compile After Delivery

weakness.name: CWE-1190
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1190: DMA Device Enabled Too Early in Boot Phase The product enables a Direct Memory Access (DMA) capable device before the security configuration settings are established, which allows an attacker to extract data from or gain privileges on the product.

weakness.name: CWE-184
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-184: Incomplete List of Disallowed Inputs The product implements a protection mechanism that relies on a list of inputs (or properties of inputs) that are not allowed by policy or otherwise require other action to neutralize before additional processing takes place, but the list is incomplete, leading to resultant weaknesses. Developers often try to protect their products against malicious input by performing tests against inputs that are known to be bad, such as special characters that can invoke new commands. However, such lists often only account for the most well-known bad inputs. Attackers may be able to find other malicious inputs that were not expected by the developer, allowing them to bypass the intended protection mechanism.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-532
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-532: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

countermeasure.name: Deploy CodeBuild projects within a VPC for network isolation
countermeasure.desc: Deploy AWS CodeBuild projects within a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) to ensure that build environments are isolated from external networks, thereby reducing exposure to external threats. Configure your VPC with appropriate security groups and network access control lists (ACLs) to control inbound and outbound traffic to the build environments. This setup ensures that only authorized internal resources can communicate with the CodeBuild environment, enhancing the security of the build process. Additionally, leverage VPC endpoints for secure access to AWS services without traversing the public internet. Implementing this control helps safeguard your build environments against unauthorized access and network-based attacks.

reference.name: Use AWS CodeBuild with Amazon Virtual Private Cloud

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-22 Architecture and Provisioning for Name/address Resolution Service

countermeasure.name: Encrypt build artifacts at rest in S3
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all build artifacts generated by AWS CodeBuild are stored in Amazon S3 with encryption enabled at rest. This prevents unauthorized access to sensitive data by protecting the artifacts using AWS-managed encryption keys (SSE-S3) or customer-managed keys (SSE-KMS). To implement this control, configure the S3 bucket that stores your build artifacts to enable server-side encryption (SSE) by default. Review and validate that all existing and new artifacts are encrypted at rest. This practice helps maintain the confidentiality and integrity of your build outputs, mitigating the risk of data breaches.

reference.name: Data encryption

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Enforce strict input validation in build scripts
countermeasure.desc: Implement strict validation of all inputs used within AWS CodeBuild scripts to prevent code injection attacks. Ensure that any parameters, environment variables, or external data consumed by build scripts are thoroughly validated for correctness, format, and security. Incorporate validation checks within the build scripts to sanitize inputs, rejecting any malformed or potentially malicious data before it is processed. Use allowlists, regular expressions, and secure coding practices to further reduce the risk of injection vulnerabilities. This control helps maintain the integrity and security of your build process by preventing unauthorized code execution.

reference.name: Security in AWS CodeBuild

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

countermeasure.name: Regularly update build environments with latest patches and software versions
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS CodeBuild environments are consistently updated with the latest security patches and software versions. This includes regularly reviewing and applying updates to the underlying operating systems, libraries, and dependencies used within your build environments. Automate the update process where possible by utilizing AWS services such as AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager or incorporating patching steps into your CI/CD pipeline. Regularly verify that your build environments are up-to-date to minimize vulnerabilities and protect against potential security threats. Maintaining current software versions is critical for the security and stability of your build processes.

reference.name: Docker images provided by CodeBuild

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to S3 buckets for build artifacts
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that access to S3 buckets storing AWS CodeBuild artifacts is tightly controlled by implementing strict permissions. Configure bucket policies and IAM roles to allow access only to authorized users and services that require it. Utilize the principle of least privilege by granting the minimum necessary permissions for accessing, modifying, or managing the build artifacts. Additionally, consider enabling logging and monitoring of access to these S3 buckets using AWS CloudTrail and Amazon S3 access logs to detect any unauthorized access attempts. Proper access control ensures the confidentiality and integrity of your build artifacts.

reference.name: Security in AWS CodeBuild

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Sanitize build logs to remove sensitive data
countermeasure.desc: Implement log sanitization processes within AWS CodeBuild to ensure that any sensitive data, such as credentials, API keys, or personally identifiable information (PII), is removed or obfuscated before logs are stored or shared. This can be achieved by incorporating log filtering mechanisms in your build scripts or using custom logging configurations that exclude sensitive information. Regularly audit and review build logs to identify and address any inadvertent exposure of sensitive data. By sanitizing logs, you protect sensitive information from unauthorized access and reduce the risk of data leakage.

reference.name: Help protect sensitive log data with masking

countermeasure.name: Use approved and hardened build images
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that only approved and security-hardened build images are used in AWS CodeBuild projects. Maintain a curated list of build images that have been vetted for security vulnerabilities and are configured according to your organization's security standards. Regularly update these images to include the latest security patches and remove outdated or vulnerable ones. Enforce the use of these approved images by restricting the selection of build environments in your CodeBuild project configurations. This control helps minimize the risk of executing malicious scripts and enhances the overall security of your build process.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Sensitive data in logs
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data in logs occurs when confidential information, such as credentials or personal data, is inadvertently recorded in AWS CodeBuild logs. This can lead to unauthorized access if the logs are improperly secured or accessed by unauthorized parties.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, unauthorized users, or external attackers.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Accessing logs that contain sensitive data.
    • Exploiting insufficient log sanitization processes to retrieve confidential information.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive information leading to potential data leaks or identity theft.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust and credibility if sensitive data is exposed.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of data protection regulations, possibly resulting in legal penalties and fines.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Access: An attacker gains access to CodeBuild logs and extracts exposed API keys or credentials, which they then use to compromise other systems.
  2. Internal Data Leak: A developer inadvertently logs sensitive customer information, which is later accessed by an unauthorized internal user, leading to a data breach.
  3. Compliance Breach: Logs containing personal data are accessed without proper controls, violating data protection laws and resulting in regulatory action.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Insufficient network isolation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insufficient network isolation in AWS CodeBuild occurs when the build environment is not properly segregated from other network resources. This lack of isolation exposes the build environment to potential external threats, allowing unauthorized access, data leakage, or interference with build processes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, compromised internal systems, or malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of network misconfigurations to gain access to the build environment.
    • Lateral movement from other compromised resources within the same network.

Impacts

  • Security Breach: Unauthorized access to the build environment, leading to potential data theft or code tampering.
  • Operational Disruption: Interference with build processes, potentially resulting in failed builds or deployment of compromised code.
  • Compliance Risks: Non-compliance with security standards requiring network segmentation, possibly leading to regulatory fines.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. External Attack: An attacker exploits an unprotected network segment to gain access to CodeBuild and injects malicious code into the build pipeline.
  2. Lateral Movement: A compromised server within the same network is used to access and tamper with the build environment due to lack of network segmentation.
  3. Data Exfiltration: An attacker intercepts sensitive data transmitted between the build environment and other resources due to inadequate network isolation.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Compromised build environments
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

A compromised build environment occurs when an attacker gains unauthorized access to the infrastructure or resources used by AWS CodeBuild. This can result in the manipulation of the build process, introduction of malicious code, or exposure of sensitive data. A compromised build environment undermines the security of the entire CI/CD pipeline and can lead to severe downstream impacts on deployed applications.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, or compromised third-party tools.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of vulnerabilities in the build environment or associated infrastructure.
    • Unauthorized access due to weak security controls or misconfigurations in the build environment.

Impacts

  • Integrity Loss: Unauthorized modifications to the build process or outputs, leading to the deployment of compromised or malicious software.
  • Data Exposure: Leakage of sensitive information, including source code, credentials, and configuration files.
  • Operational Disruption: Interruption or sabotage of the build process, causing delays or deployment of flawed applications.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Infrastructure Exploit: An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the underlying infrastructure hosting the build environment, gaining control over the build process and inserting malicious code into the final product.
  2. Misconfiguration Abuse: Due to a misconfiguration, an unauthorized user gains access to the build environment, modifies build scripts, and causes the deployment of compromised software.
  3. Third-Party Tool Compromise: A third-party tool integrated into the build environment is compromised, allowing an attacker to manipulate the build process or steal sensitive data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1195.002 - Compromise Software Supply Chain

threat.name: Code injection via build scripts
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Code injection via build scripts occurs when an attacker or unauthorized user introduces malicious code into the build scripts used by AWS CodeBuild. This malicious code can then be executed during the build process, potentially compromising the integrity of the build, leaking sensitive data, or introducing vulnerabilities into the final software product.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, or compromised CI/CD systems.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Inserting malicious code directly into build scripts or configurations.
    • Exploiting vulnerabilities in third-party dependencies or plugins used in the build process.

Impacts

  • Compromised Software Integrity: Malicious code could be embedded in the final software product, leading to security vulnerabilities or backdoors.
  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive information might be extracted and sent to unauthorized parties during the build process.
  • Operational Disruption: The build process could be sabotaged, resulting in failed builds or deployment of insecure code.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Script Manipulation: An attacker gains access to the build script repository and injects malicious code that exfiltrates sensitive data during the build process, which is then sent to an external server.
  2. Third-Party Dependency Exploit: A malicious actor exploits a vulnerability in a third-party library or plugin integrated into the build script, leading to the execution of unauthorized code during the build.
  3. Insider Attack: A disgruntled employee inserts malicious code into the build scripts, which, once deployed, opens a backdoor in the application for future exploitation.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

  3. Third-Party Tool Compromise: A third-party tool integrated into the build environment is compromised, allowing an attacker to manipulate the build process or steal sensitive data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1195.002 - Compromise Software Supply Chain

threat.name: Code injection via build scripts
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Code injection via build scripts occurs when an attacker or unauthorized user introduces malicious code into the build scripts used by AWS CodeBuild. This malicious code can then be executed during the build process, potentially compromising the integrity of the build, leaking sensitive data, or introducing vulnerabilities into the final software product.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, or compromised CI/CD systems.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Inserting malicious code directly into build scripts or configurations.
    • Exploiting vulnerabilities in third-party dependencies or plugins used in the build process.

Impacts

  • Compromised Software Integrity: Malicious code could be embedded in the final software product, leading to security vulnerabilities or backdoors.
  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive information might be extracted and sent to unauthorized parties during the build process.
  • Operational Disruption: The build process could be sabotaged, resulting in failed builds or deployment of insecure code.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Script Manipulation: An attacker gains access to the build script repository and injects malicious code that exfiltrates sensitive data during the build process, which is then sent to an external server.
  2. Third-Party Dependency Exploit: A malicious actor exploits a vulnerability in a third-party library or plugin integrated into the build script, leading to the execution of unauthorized code during the build.
  3. Insider Attack: A disgruntled employee inserts malicious code into the build scripts, which, once deployed, opens a backdoor in the application for future exploitation.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

threat.name: Unauthorized access to build artifacts
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized access to build artifacts occurs when individuals or entities gain access to the files, binaries, or other outputs generated by AWS CodeBuild without proper authorization. This can lead to the exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized code changes, or distribution of compromised software.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, unauthorized internal users, or compromised build systems.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting misconfigured S3 bucket permissions where build artifacts are stored.
    • Gaining access through over-permissioned IAM roles associated with the build environment.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive or proprietary code and data contained in build artifacts.
  • Operational Risk: Deployment of compromised or altered software, leading to potential security vulnerabilities.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer trust if compromised artifacts are distributed.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Misconfigured S3 Bucket: An attacker exploits a publicly accessible S3 bucket containing build artifacts, downloads the artifacts, and discovers sensitive information or injects malicious code.
  2. Internal Misuse: An insider with excessive permissions accesses build artifacts and modifies them, leading to the deployment of unauthorized code in a production environment.
  3. Artifact Tampering: An attacker gains access to artifacts stored in an insecure location, alters the files, and these compromised files are later deployed, resulting in a security breach.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1500 - Compile After Delivery

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-359
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

countermeasure.name: Consider integrating manual approval actions in your pipeline
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing manual approval actions within your AWS CodePipeline ensures that code and configuration modifications undergo review and authorization by designated personnel before proceeding to deployment. By integrating these manual approval steps, you can maintain high security and compliance standards, mitigating risks associated with unauthorized or potentially harmful changes.

To configure manual approval actions in AWS CodePipeline, follow these steps:

  1. In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the CodePipeline section and select the pipeline where you want to add a manual approval action.
  2. Edit the pipeline and insert a new stage or modify an existing stage to include a manual approval action.
  3. When defining this action, specify the necessary approvers. These should be IAM users or groups with the appropriate permissions to approve the deployment.
  4. Configure notifications for the approval action, ensuring approvers are promptly informed when their review is required. This can be integrated with AWS SNS or other communication tools.
  5. Document the approval process including the criteria for approval and ensure all stakeholders are aligned with the procedure.

For detailed steps and security considerations, refer to the Manual Approval Actions in AWS CodePipeline.

countermeasure.name: Implement versioning and change tracking for pipeline configurations
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security and auditability of your AWS CodePipeline configurations, it is critical to implement versioning and change tracking mechanisms. This countermeasure ensures that all changes made to pipeline configurations are tracked, logged, and auditable, making it easier to detect unauthorized changes.

Heres how you can implement this control:

  • Enable Versioning: Utilize AWS CodePipelines built-in features to maintain version history of your pipeline configurations. Every change to the pipeline should create a new version, allowing you to track the evolution of the pipeline settings over time.
  • Utilize AWS CloudTrail: Configure AWS CloudTrail to log API calls related to CodePipeline. CloudTrail provides a comprehensive event history, enabling you to monitor and track changes made to your pipeline configurations. For detailed setup, refer to the AWS CodePipeline Security Documentation.
  • Implement Code Reviews: Use AWS CodeCommit or another version control system to store your pipeline configuration files. Implement code review processes to ensure that all configuration changes are reviewed and approved before deployment.
  • Audit and Monitor Changes: Regularly audit the changes logged by CloudTrail and version control systems to verify that all changes are authorized. Set up Amazon CloudWatch alarms to notify you of any unexpected changes to critical pipeline settings. For more details, reference the AWS CodePipeline Versioning and Change Control documentation.

By following these guidelines, you ensure that all modifications to your pipeline configurations are tracked and auditable, strengthening the overall security posture of your AWS CodePipeline setup.

countermeasure.name: Use encryption and authentication for the source repositories that connect to your pipelines
countermeasure.desc:
These are the CodePipeline best practices for security:

  • If you create a pipeline or action configuration that needs to include secrets, such as tokens or passwords, do not enter secrets directly in the action configuration, or default values of variables defined at pipeline level or AWS CloudFormation configuration, because the information will display in logs. Use Secrets Manager to set up and store secrets, and then use the referenced secret in the pipeline and action configuration, as described in Use AWS Secrets Manager to track database passwords or third-party API keys.
  • If you create a pipeline that uses an S3 source bucket, configure server-side encryption for artifacts stored in Amazon S3 for CodePipeline by managing AWS KMS keys, as described in Configure server-side encryption for artifacts stored in Amazon S3 for CodePipeline.
  • If you are using the Jenkins action provider, when you use a Jenkins build provider for your pipelines build or test action, install Jenkins on an EC2 instance and configure a separate EC2 instance profile. Make sure that the instance profile grants Jenkins only the AWS permissions required to perform tasks for your project, such as retrieving files from Amazon S3. To learn how to create the role for your Jenkins instance profile, see the steps in Create an IAM role to use for Jenkins integration.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data leakage through pipeline artifacts
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly secured pipeline artifacts can result in unauthorized access to sensitive data, leading to data breaches and leakage.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users or malicious insiders who gain access to improperly secured artifacts stored in the pipeline.
Impacts
Exposure of sensitive data, financial loss, damage to reputation, and potential legal consequences due to data privacy violations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an unprotected S3 bucket where pipeline artifacts are stored and exfiltrates sensitive information, leading to a major data breach.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Pipeline configuration manipulation
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized changes to the pipeline configuration might lead to unintended deployments or security vulnerabilities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal or external attackers gaining access to the AWS CodePipeline configuration, potentially through compromised credentials or insufficient access controls, and making unauthorized modifications.
Impacts
The integrity and reliability of software deployments could be compromised, resulting in the release of unapproved or insecure code, data breaches, or operational disruptions.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to the AWS CodePipeline configuration through a leaked API key and modifies the pipeline steps to deploy malicious code to production. Alternatively, a disgruntled employee with elevated permissions changes the configuration to redirect deployments to a personal server, leading to data exfiltration.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations

threat.name: Code injection vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Malicious actors might inject unauthorized code into the pipeline, leading to compromised application code or data exfiltration.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include external attackers or malicious insiders. Attack vectors include exploiting vulnerabilities in the pipeline's security configurations, leveraging compromised credentials, or exploiting unsecured APIs.
Impacts
Impacts can include the deployment of compromised applications, leading to sensitive data leaks, financial loss, damage to the organization's reputation, and potential legal ramifications.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to the pipeline through compromised credentials and injects malicious code that exfiltrates customer data. Alternatively, a malicious insider injects harmful code during the build process, which gets deployed to production, compromising the application's integrity.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-327
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-327: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm The product uses a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm or protocol.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

countermeasure.name: Configure Key Policies to Require MFA for Key Deletion and Enable Scheduled Key Deletion
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of AWS KMS keys, configure key policies to require Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for key deletion and enable scheduled key deletion to provide a recovery window. This ensures that unauthorized or accidental deletion of keys is prevented by adding an additional layer of security and provides a time buffer for recovery.

Steps to Implement the Control:

  1. Require MFA for Key Deletion:
    • Navigate to the AWS KMS Console.
    • Select the key for which you want to configure MFA.
    • Edit the key policy to include a condition that requires MFA for the kms:ScheduleKeyDeletion action. The policy should include the aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent condition key.
    • Example key policy snippet:{    "Sid": "Require MFA for Key Deletion",    "Effect": "Deny",    "Principal": {        "AWS": "*"    },    "Action": "kms:ScheduleKeyDeletion",    "Resource": "*",    "Condition": {        "BoolIfExists": {            "aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent": "false"        }    } }
    • Review and save the updated key policy.
  2. Enable Scheduled Key Deletion:
    • Use the schedule-key-deletion API or the AWS Console to enable scheduled deletion.
    • Specify a deletion window (7 to 30 days) to allow for any recovery actions if needed.
    • Example AWS CLI command:aws kms schedule-key-deletion --key-id  --pending-window-in-days 30

Refer to the AWS KMS Key Policy guidelines and Scheduled Key Deletion documentation for more detailed instructions.

countermeasure.name: Implement key management best practices
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your encryption keys in AWS KMS, follow the AWS key management best practices to ensure keys are managed securely throughout their lifecycle. Implementing these best practices will help mitigate risks and enforce strong security postures for your cryptographic operations.

Steps to Implement:

  • Enable Key Rotation: Configure automatic key rotation for your customer managed keys (CMKs) to replace older keys with new cryptographic material regularly, reducing the potential impact of key compromise. Reference: Managing Key Rotation .
  • Use Unique Keys per Application: For better isolation and control, create separate keys for different applications and data sets. This limits the exposure and isolates the impact if a key is compromised. Reference: AWS KMS Best Practices.
  • Define Key Policies Carefully: Apply the principle of least privilege when defining key policies to restrict access strictly to necessary identities and operations. Regularly review and audit these policies. Reference: Using Key Policies in AWS KMS.
  • Monitor Key Usage: Enable AWS CloudTrail logs to track all KMS API calls and key usage. Leverage CloudWatch to set up alerts for unusual key usage patterns. Reference: Logging AWS KMS API Calls with AWS CloudTrail.
  • Secure Key Deletion: Use multi-step processes for deleting encryption keys, such as scheduling keys for deletion with a substantial waiting period to prevent accidental data loss. Reference: Deleting a Customer Managed Key.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS KMS VPC endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that key operations occur within a securely isolated network environment, it is recommended to use AWS KMS VPC endpoints. This approach allows you to securely access AWS KMS within your Amazon VPC, eliminating the need for internet access or public IP addresses. By doing so, you enhance the security of your cryptographic operations and key management tasks.

Implementation Guidance:

  1. Create a VPC Endpoint for KMS: Navigate to the VPC Console, select Endpoints, and create a VPC endpoint for the com.amazonaws..kms service. Ensure that you select the appropriate VPC and subnets where your resources reside.
  2. Attach Security Groups: Attach security groups to the VPC endpoint to control access to the KMS service. Define rules that permit only trusted sources to communicate with the KMS endpoint.
  3. Update KMS Policy: Modify the KMS key policy to allow access through the VPC endpoint. This involves adding a condition to the policy that restricts access based on the source VPC or VPC endpoint.
  4. Test the Configuration: Once configured, validate that your resources within the VPC can access AWS KMS through the VPC endpoint. Ensure there are no public IP addresses or internet gateways involved in the communication.

References:

  • For more detailed instructions, visit the AWS KMS VPC Endpoint Documentation.
  • Refer to the official security guidelines at AWS Key Management Service Security.

countermeasure.name: Use customer managed keys (CMKs)
countermeasure.desc:
Countermeasure: Opt for customer managed keys and enforce strict access controls to mitigate the risk of key compromise

To enhance the security of your cryptographic keys within the AWS Key Management Service (KMS), it is highly recommended to use customer managed keys (CMKs) alongside rigorous access control policies. This measure helps in mitigating the risk of key compromise. Heres how a cloud engineer can implement this control:

1. Create Customer Managed Keys (CMKs)

Customer managed keys allow for granular control and extensive permissions management. Start by creating a CMK via the AWS Management Console, AWS CLI, or AWS SDKs.

  • Refer to the official documentation on creating CMKs: Creating Keys

2. Enforce Strict Access Controls

Enforce strict access control by defining carefully scoped IAM policies to restrict who can use and manage your CMKs.

  • Use the kms:ViaService condition key in policies to restrict the use of the key to specific AWS services.
  • Apply least privilege principle by defining actions and resources narrowly tailored to specific roles or users.

More details on IAM policy conditions can be found here: Key Policy Conditions

3. Implement Key Policies and Grants

Combine key policies and grants to further tighten control over who and how your keys can be used.

  • Use key policies to manage permissions at the key level and ensure they are aligned with your organizations security policies.
  • Use grants to allow temporary, scoped access to CMKs and revoke them as soon as they are no longer needed.

Refer to the following for more information: Key Policy Overview and Using Grants

4. Regularly Audit Key Usage

Regularly monitor and audit the usage of your CMKs using AWS CloudTrail. Set up alerts for any suspicious activities or policy changes.

  • Review AWS CloudTrail logs and filter by KMS API events to track key usage.

1.2 - Ensure security contact information is registered
2.3.1 - Ensure that encryption is enabled for EFS file systems
3.5 - Ensure CloudTrail logs are encrypted at rest using KMS CMKs
4.6 - Ensure AWS Management Console authentication failures are monitored
5.1.1 - Ensure EBS volume encryption is enabled in all regions
CWE-200: CWE-200

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Data loss from key deletion
threat.desc:
General threat description
Accidental or malicious deletion of cryptographic keys can pose a significant risk, as it can lead to the irreversible loss of any data encrypted with those keys.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users, compromised accounts, or even legitimate users making errors may delete cryptographic keys, whether intentionally or accidentally.
Impacts
Permanent data loss, inability to decrypt critical information, potential downtime, and significant business disruption. This can also lead to legal and compliance issues if the lost data pertains to sensitive information subject to regulatory requirements.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains access to a compromised IAM account and deletes several critical KMS keys, rendering associated encrypted data unusable.
2. An employee mistakenly deletes a KMS key used to encrypt customer data backups, resulting in the company being unable to restore data during a recovery process.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data interception during key operations
threat.desc:
General threat description
Sensitive key materials used during encryption, decryption, or other cryptographic operations may be intercepted if not adequately protected.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
External attackers or malicious insiders may exploit vulnerabilities in network communication, application code, or cloud infrastructure to capture key materials.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to encrypted data, breach of sensitive information, financial loss, regulatory non-compliance, and damage to organizational reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker manages to exploit a vulnerable API endpoint to intercept key materials, allowing them to decrypt confidential data. Alternatively, a malicious insider with sufficient privileges accesses key management logs where keys are inadequately protected, leading to unauthorized decryption of sensitive information.

threat.name: Weak key management practices
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper handling and management of encryption keys can result in unauthorized access, data breaches, or loss of critical information.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors may exploit vulnerabilities in key storage, poor rotation policies, or misuse by untrained personnel to gain unauthorized access to encrypted data.
Impacts
Potential impacts include data breaches, financial loss, loss of reputation, and regulatory penalties due to the exposure or misuse of sensitive information.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to unrotated encryption keys stored in plaintext and decrypts sensitive data. Another scenario might involve a former employee using an outdated and poorly managed key to access confidential company information.

threat.name: Compromised encryption keys
threat.desc:
General threat description
Compromised encryption keys can lead to unauthorized data decryption, resulting in significant data breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can gain access to encryption keys through various means such as phishing attacks, exploiting weak permissions, or vulnerabilities in the key management system.
Impacts
Unauthorized data decryption can expose sensitive information, resulting in data breaches, financial loss, reputational damage, regulatory fines, and loss of customer trust.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker successfully phishes an administrators credentials, accesses the AWS Management Console, and retrieves the KMS keys, which are then used to decrypt sensitive customer data stored in S3 buckets. Another scenario includes exploiting a vulnerability in the key management system to escalate privileges and extract the encryption keys.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-327
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-327: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm The product uses a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm or protocol.

weakness.name: CWE-732
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-732: Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource The product specifies permissions for a security-critical resource in a way that allows that resource to be read or modified by unintended actors. When a resource is given a permission setting that provides access to a wider range of actors than required, it could lead to the exposure of sensitive information, or the modification of that resource by unintended parties. This is especially dangerous when the resource is related to program configuration, execution, or sensitive user data. For example, consider a misconfigured storage account for the cloud that can be read or written by a public or anonymous user.

countermeasure.name: Configure Key Policies to Require MFA for Key Deletion and Enable Scheduled Key Deletion
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of AWS KMS keys, configure key policies to require Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for key deletion and enable scheduled key deletion to provide a recovery window. This ensures that unauthorized or accidental deletion of keys is prevented by adding an additional layer of security and provides a time buffer for recovery.

Steps to Implement the Control:

  1. Require MFA for Key Deletion:
    • Navigate to the AWS KMS Console.
    • Select the key for which you want to configure MFA.
    • Edit the key policy to include a condition that requires MFA for the kms:ScheduleKeyDeletion action. The policy should include the aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent condition key.
    • Example key policy snippet:{    "Sid": "Require MFA for Key Deletion",    "Effect": "Deny",    "Principal": {        "AWS": "*"    },    "Action": "kms:ScheduleKeyDeletion",    "Resource": "*",    "Condition": {        "BoolIfExists": {            "aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent": "false"        }    } }
    • Review and save the updated key policy.
  2. Enable Scheduled Key Deletion:
    • Use the schedule-key-deletion API or the AWS Console to enable scheduled deletion.
    • Specify a deletion window (7 to 30 days) to allow for any recovery actions if needed.
    • Example AWS CLI command:aws kms schedule-key-deletion --key-id  --pending-window-in-days 30

Refer to the AWS KMS Key Policy guidelines and Scheduled Key Deletion documentation for more detailed instructions.

reference.name: 1 1.5 - Ensure hardware MFA is enabled for the 'root' user account
1.11 - Ensure credentials unused for 45 days or more are disabled
1.4 - Ensure MFA is enabled for the 'root' user account
1.7 - Ensure IAM password policy requires minimum length of 14 or greater
1.8 - Ensure IAM password policy prevents password reuse
1.9 - Ensure multi-factor authentication (MFA) is enabled for all IAM users that have a console password
2.1.2 - Ensure MFA Delete is enabled on S3 buckets
4.2 - Ensure management console sign-in without MFA is monitored
4.4 - Ensure IAM policy changes are monitored
4.7 - Ensure disabling or scheduled deletion of customer created CMKs is monitored
4.8 - Ensure S3 bucket policy changes are monitored
CWE-732: CWE-732

countermeasure.name: Implement key management best practices
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your encryption keys in AWS KMS, follow the AWS key management best practices to ensure keys are managed securely throughout their lifecycle. Implementing these best practices will help mitigate risks and enforce strong security postures for your cryptographic operations.

Steps to Implement:

  • Enable Key Rotation: Configure automatic key rotation for your customer managed keys (CMKs) to replace older keys with new cryptographic material regularly, reducing the potential impact of key compromise. Reference: Managing Key Rotation .
  • Use Unique Keys per Application: For better isolation and control, create separate keys for different applications and data sets. This limits the exposure and isolates the impact if a key is compromised. Reference: AWS KMS Best Practices.
  • Define Key Policies Carefully: Apply the principle of least privilege when defining key policies to restrict access strictly to necessary identities and operations. Regularly review and audit these policies. Reference: Using Key Policies in AWS KMS.
  • Monitor Key Usage: Enable AWS CloudTrail logs to track all KMS API calls and key usage. Leverage CloudWatch to set up alerts for unusual key usage patterns. Reference: Logging AWS KMS API Calls with AWS CloudTrail.
  • Secure Key Deletion: Use multi-step processes for deleting encryption keys, such as scheduling keys for deletion with a substantial waiting period to prevent accidental data loss. Reference: Deleting a Customer Managed Key.

reference.name: 1.10 - Do not create access keys during initial setup for IAM users with a console password
1.13 - Ensure access keys are rotated every 90 days or less
1.15 - Ensure IAM policies that allow full administrative privileges are not attached
1.18 - Ensure that all expired SSL/TLS certificates stored in AWS IAM are removed
1.3 - Ensure no 'root' user account access key exists
3.6 - Ensure rotation for customer-created symmetric CMKs is enabled
CWE-200: CWE-200

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

countermeasure.name: Use AWS KMS VPC endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that key operations occur within a securely isolated network environment, it is recommended to use AWS KMS VPC endpoints. This approach allows you to securely access AWS KMS within your Amazon VPC, eliminating the need for internet access or public IP addresses. By doing so, you enhance the security of your cryptographic operations and key management tasks.

Implementation Guidance:

  1. Create a VPC Endpoint for KMS: Navigate to the VPC Console, select Endpoints, and create a VPC endpoint for the com.amazonaws..kms service. Ensure that you select the appropriate VPC and subnets where your resources reside.
  2. Attach Security Groups: Attach security groups to the VPC endpoint to control access to the KMS service. Define rules that permit only trusted sources to communicate with the KMS endpoint.
  3. Update KMS Policy: Modify the KMS key policy to allow access through the VPC endpoint. This involves adding a condition to the policy that restricts access based on the source VPC or VPC endpoint.
  4. Test the Configuration: Once configured, validate that your resources within the VPC can access AWS KMS through the VPC endpoint. Ensure there are no public IP addresses or internet gateways involved in the communication.

References:

  • For more detailed instructions, visit the AWS KMS VPC Endpoint Documentation.
  • Refer to the official security guidelines at AWS Key Management Service Security.

reference.name: 2.1.4 - Ensure that S3 is configured with 'Block Public Access' enabled
3.3 - Ensure AWS Config is enabled in all regions
CWE-200: CWE-200

Potential impacts include data breaches, financial loss, loss of reputation, and regulatory penalties due to the exposure or misuse of sensitive information.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to unrotated encryption keys stored in plaintext and decrypts sensitive data. Another scenario might involve a former employee using an outdated and poorly managed key to access confidential company information.

threat.name: Compromised encryption keys
threat.desc:
General threat description
Compromised encryption keys can lead to unauthorized data decryption, resulting in significant data breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can gain access to encryption keys through various means such as phishing attacks, exploiting weak permissions, or vulnerabilities in the key management system.
Impacts
Unauthorized data decryption can expose sensitive information, resulting in data breaches, financial loss, reputational damage, regulatory fines, and loss of customer trust.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker successfully phishes an administrators credentials, accesses the AWS Management Console, and retrieves the KMS keys, which are then used to decrypt sensitive customer data stored in S3 buckets. Another scenario includes exploiting a vulnerability in the key management system to escalate privileges and extract the encryption keys.

weakness.name: CWE-1047
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1047: Modules with Circular Dependencies The product contains modules in which one module has references that cycle back to itself, i.e., there are circular dependencies.

weakness.name: CWE-1193
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1193: Power-On of Untrusted Execution Core Before Enabling Fabric Access Control The product enables components that contain untrusted firmware before memory and fabric access controls have been enabled.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-300
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-300: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint. In order to establish secure communication between two parties, it is often important to adequately verify the identity of entities at each end of the communication channel. Inadequate or inconsistent verification may result in insufficient or incorrect identification of either communicating entity. This can have negative consequences such as misplaced trust in the entity at the other end of the channel. An attacker can leverage this by interposing between the communicating entities and masquerading as the original entity. In the absence of sufficient verification of identity, such an attacker can eavesdrop and potentially modify the communication between the original entities.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-312
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-312: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information in cleartext within a resource that might be accessible to another control sphere.

weakness.name: CWE-353
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-353: Missing Support for Integrity Check The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission, such as a checksum. If integrity check values or "checksums" are omitted from a protocol, there is no way of determining if data has been corrupted in transmission. The lack of checksum functionality in a protocol removes the first application-level check of data that can be used. The end-to-end philosophy of checks states that integrity checks should be performed at the lowest level that they can be completely implemented. Excluding further sanity checks and input validation performed by applications, the protocol's checksum is the most important level of checksum, since it can be performed more completely than at any previous level and takes into account entire messages, as opposed to single packets.

weakness.name: CWE-384
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-384: Session Fixation Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.

weakness.name: CWE-416
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-416: Use After Free Referencing memory after it has been freed can cause a program to crash, use unexpected values, or execute code.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-540
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-540: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example, obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

weakness.name: CWE-672
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-672: Operation on a Resource after Expiration or Release The product uses, accesses, or otherwise operates on a resource after that resource has been expired, released, or revoked.

weakness.name: CWE-913
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-913: Improper Control of Dynamically-Managed Code Resources The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-managed code resources such as variables, objects, classes, attributes, functions, or executable instructions or statements. Many languages offer powerful features that allow the programmer to dynamically create or modify existing code, or resources used by code such as variables and objects. While these features can offer significant flexibility and reduce development time, they can be extremely dangerous if attackers can directly influence these code resources in unexpected ways.

countermeasure.name: Apply permission boundaries to cap Lambda role and user privileges
countermeasure.desc:
Define a single IAM permission-boundary policy that represents the maximum set of actions a Lambda workload should ever performtypically the core lambda:*, CloudWatch Logs calls, and tightly scoped access to specific AWS resources. Attach that boundary to:

  • Every Lambda execution role (via the PermissionBoundary property in CloudFormation/Terraform).
  • All human or CI/CD principals that can create or update functions.

Because AWS evaluates the boundary before attached or inline policies, anything not explicitly allowed by the boundary is automatically deniedeven if someone tries to grant broader rights later.

quick implementation

  1. Author and publish the boundary
    1. {
       "Version":"2012-10-17",
       "Statement":[
         { "Effect":"Allow", "Action":[
             "lambda:*",
             "logs:CreateLogGroup", "logs:CreateLogStream", "logs:PutLogEvents"
           ], "Resource":"*" },
         { "Effect":"Deny", "Action":[ "iam:*", "organizations:*", "lambda:DeleteFunction" ], "Resource":"*" }
       ]
      }
       
    2. aws iam create-policy --policy-name lambda-boundary --policy-document file://boundary.json
  2. Attach the boundary
    1. aws iam put-role-permissions-boundary \
          --role-name OrderProcessorRole \
          --permissions-boundary arn:aws:iam::<acct>:policy/lambda-boundary
  3. Enforce automatically
    • Add a pipeline check (e.g., cfn-lint, Checkov) that fails if a new role lacks PermissionBoundary.
    • Enable AWS Config rule iam-user-permissions-boundary-check and create a similar custom rule for roles to detect drift.
  4. Maintain
    Review the boundary every quarter: remove unused Allow actions, add new ones only after peer approval, and keep the policy version history in source control.

References

  • Permissions boundaries for IAM entities
  • Lambda security best practices IAM boundaries

standard.ref: Consumers Less Than Under 13 Years of Age (c)
PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes
PR.AC-6: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Deploy VPC Lambda functions across multiple Availability Zones
countermeasure.desc:
For every Lambda function that runs inside a VPC, attach at least two private subnets that reside in different Availability Zones (AZs). Lambda automatically spreads function instances across all subnets you specify, so providing subnets in multiple AZs gives the function resiliency against an AZ-level failure.

Implementation steps

  1. Subnet planning In the target VPC, create two or more /24 (or smaller) private subnets, each located in a distinct AZ (for example, subnet-az1a-private, subnet-az1b-private). If the function needs outbound internet access, give every AZ its own NAT gateway or egress path.
  2. Configure the function
    • Console: Configuration VPC Edit select the VPC and tick both (or all) private subnets.
    • AWS CLI / IaC:
      • aws lambda update-function-configuration \
         --function-name order-processor \
         --vpc-config SubnetIds=subnet-0a12,subnet-0b34,SecurityGroupIds=sg-0abc
  3. Security groups Attach a least-privilege security group that allows only the ports and CIDRs the function truly needs (for example, TCP 5432 to an RDS cluster SG).
  4. Guardrails Implement an AWS Config custom rule or cfn-nag check that fails a deployment when a VPC-connected Lambda lists fewer than two subnets.
  5. Validation & monitoring Use the Lambda consoles Monitoring Subnet metrics or CloudWatchs Duration metrics to confirm invocations appear from each AZ. Include a canary test that fires if an AZs invocations drop to zero.

Spreading subnets across Availability Zones ensures the function continues to invoke even if one AZor its networking componentsbecomes unavailable.

References

  • AWS Lambda resilience guidance
  • Create more than one subnet across different AZ

countermeasure.name: Encrypt Lambda env vars and code artifacts with customer-managed KMS keys
countermeasure.desc:
Safeguard every sensitive value that AWS Lambda storesenvironment variables, .zip deployment packages, container images, and event-filter criteriaby encrypting them with an AWS KMS customer-managed key (CMK) instead of the default AWS-managed key. Using your own CMK lets you control key rotation, scope decrypt permissions tightly, and audit every use.

1 . Create or choose a CMK

aws kms create-key --description "Lambda data-at-rest CMK"
aws kms enable-key-rotation --key-id <key-id>

Limit the key policy to the Lambda service principal and the minimal set of roles that need kms:Decrypt / kms:GenerateDataKey.

2 . Encrypt environment variables

  • Console / IaC: set the KMS key ARN field (CloudFormation KmsKeyArn, Terraform kms_key_arn).
  • CLI:
    • aws lambda update-function-configuration \
          --function-name order-processor \
          --kms-key-arn arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd

Lambda now uses your CMK to encrypt Env Vars and event-filter JSON.

3 . Protect deployment artifacts

  • .zip packages in S3 store them in a bucket with SSE-KMS and the same CMK:
    • aws s3api put-bucket-encryption \
          --bucket lambda-artifacts-prod \
          --server-side-encryption-configuration \
          '{"Rules":[{"ApplyServerSideEncryptionByDefault":
             {"SSEAlgorithm":"aws:kms","KMSMasterKeyID":"alias/lambda-data"}}]}'
  • Container images in ECR ensure the ECR repository uses KMS encryption with your CMK.

4 . Grant least-privilege KMS access

Add this statement (scoped to the CMK ARN) to the functions execution role:

{
 "Effect": "Allow",
 "Action": [
   "kms:Decrypt",
   "kms:GenerateDataKey*"
 ],
 "Resource": "arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd"
}

5 . Continuous assurance

  • Enable AWS Config rule lambda-function-env-vars-encrypted (or a custom rule) to flag functions without a CMK.
  • Create CloudWatch alarms on KMS metric NumberOfFailedDecryptRequests.
  • Rotate the CMK annually; update KmsKeyArn in templates, then disable the old key after confirming no decrypt errors.

Encrypting Lambda data with your own KMS keys gives you full custody of cryptographic material, meets stringent compliance mandates, and lets you trace every decrypt back to an invoking principal.

References

  • Encrypting environment variables and artifacts with a customer-managed KMS key
  • Using AWS KMS keys with AWS Lambda

standard.ref: PM-17 Protecting Controlled Unclassified Information on External Systems

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Enforce bootstrap-aware CI/CD reviews and linting
countermeasure.desc:
To implement the security countermeasure that safeguards AWS Lambda custom runtimes by treating 'bootstrap' and Lambda runtime layers as sensitive code, follow the steps outlined below:

  1. Establish a Peer Review Process:
    • Define a policy that mandates peer reviews for any changes to files named 'bootstrap' or runtime layers containing 'bootstrap'.
    • Implement a system in your version control platform (e.g., GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket) that explicitly requires an "approval" label before merging code involving these sensitive components.
    • Ensure that reviewers are experienced in security practices and familiar with Lambda runtimes.
  2. Deploy Static Code Analysis Tools:
    • Integrate static analysis tools (e.g., Checkmarx, SonarQube) into the CI/CD pipeline.
    • Configure these tools to flag and fail builds when detected risky constructs such as:
      • curl, wget, or nc
      • Any usage of bash -c
      • Unchecked or blind network egress calls
    • Introduce an allowlist mechanism where risky constructs can only bypass checks if accompanied by a written, justified reason reviewed and approved by security teams.
  3. Restrict Bootstrap Role:
    • Verify that the 'bootstrap' file solely performs runtime initialization tasks and invokes the handler or Runtime Interface Client (RIC) as designed.
    • Apply rules to forbid any embedded persistence, telemetry beacons, or additional functionality within the 'bootstrap', unless explicitly approved through the peer-review process.
    • Audit the 'bootstrap' code periodically to ensure compliance with these restrictions.
  4. Enforce Pipeline-Only Deployment:
    • Block any direct uploads of Lambda runtime layers or the 'bootstrap' file via the AWS Management Console.
    • Configure permissions so that developers can only deploy changes through a CI/CD pipeline that enforces defined security checks.
    • Apply IAM policies to prevent unauthorized access to runtime layer modification workflows.

References

  • Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat - When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor
  • AWS Lambda Official Documentation
  • AWS CodePipeline Documentation
  • AWS Security Blog

countermeasure.name: Enforce code-signed Lambda deployments with AWS Signer
countermeasure.desc:
Guarantee that only vetted code reaches production by pairing AWS Signer with a Lambda Code Signing Configuration (CSC): every deployment package must be signed with your approved signing profile before Lambda accepts it.

  1. Create a signing profile
    1. aws signer put-signing-profile \
       --profile-name prod-lambda-code \
       --platform-id AWSLambda-SHA384-ECDSA
  2. Store the profile ARN in your CI/CD secrets.
  3. Integrate signing into the pipeline
    • Package the ZIP or container image, then call aws signer start-signing-job (ZIP) or ECR image signing (container).
    • Fail the build if the signing job status isnt Succeeded.
  4. Define a Code Signing Configuration
    1. aws lambda create-code-signing-config \
       --allowed-publishers SigningProfileVersionArns=arn:aws:signer::profile/prod-lambda-code/* \
       --code-signing-policies UntrustedArtifactOnDeployment=Enforce
  5. Enforce blocks any unsigned or differently-signed artifact.
  6. Attach the CSC to functions
    1. aws lambda update-function-code-signing-config \
       --function-name orders-handler \
       --code-signing-config-arn arn:aws:lambda::code-signing-config:csc-abc123
  7. Include this step in all CloudFormation/Terraform modules so drift is impossible.
  8. Guardrails & monitoring
    • Enable the AWS Config rule lambda-function-code-signing-config-enabled to detect functions without a CSC.
    • Use EventBridge to alert when a deployment fails due to CodeSigningError, signalling a bypass attempt or pipeline mis-sign.
  9. Key hygiene
    • Rotate the Signer KMS key annually; update the signing profile to the new key version.
    • Restrict signer:StartSigningJob permission to the build role; deny it in production accounts via SCPs.

By requiring AWS-signed packages and enforcing CSCs, you shut the door on tampered artifacts, typo-squatted libraries, and shadow deployments.

References

  • Code signing for AWS Lambda
  • AWS Signer Developer Guide
